title: Vienna terror attack: Europe will not give in to its enemies, says defiant Macron
text:
President Macron has had to contend with three Islamist terrorist attacks in France in the past six weeks

President Macron was swift to deliver a message of support to Austria and defiance in the face of terrorism last night.

Mr Macron telephoned Sebastian Kurz, the Austrian chancellor, to “express his total solidarity and support and to offer the help of France if necessary,” the Élysée Palace said.

Sponsored

The French president’s words had particular resonance after three terrorist attacks in France in the past six weeks, all carried out by Islamists. France is seeking to rally the EU around its uncompromising line on Islamist terrorism.

On Twitter, Mr Macron said: “After France, it is a country with whom we are friends that is attacked. This is our Europe. Our enemies must know who they are dealing with. We will not give up.” He made

title: Letters to the Editor: dump the ignoble nobles and ban the tarnished gongs
text:
Unlike your leader writer (Editorial, last week), I am delighted to see the

appalling Peter Cruddas “elevated” to the House of Lords. I also hope Boris Johnson ennobles still more IRA and KGB acolytes, the rest of his family and the entire chumocracy.

Those beacons of entrepreneurial excellence, Sir Philip and Lady Green, deserve a peerage apiece; and by looking further afield — Lord Putin of St Petersburg, perhaps, and some ermine-clad Chinese kleptocrats — we would show the world that post-Brexit Britain is truly open for business.

Sponsored

Much more of this, and we might even get an elected second chamber, like every other democracy. Go on, Boris, you can do it.

Rosemary Sealey, Canterbury

The ennoblement of Peter Cruddas delighted at least one Sunday Times reader REX/SHUTTERSTOCK

Chopping block

I do not know where to

title: Boris Johnson backtracks on prosecuting tech bosses who fail children
text:
Molly Russell, 14, killed herself in 2017 after viewing self-harm images on social media. Her father, Ian Russell, said that without the threat of criminal liability the new regulatory regime would be “half-hearted”

Boris Johnson has been accused of diluting plans for laws that would leave social media executives facing prosecution for failing to protect children.

The government is due to publish its response to a consultation on a proposal to regulate tech giants within the next fortnight.

Sponsored

Ministers will introduce a statutory duty of care, which will be enforced by Ofcom, the broadcasting regulator. Companies that breach the duty could face multimillion-pound fines or be blocked from operating in Britain.

However, a plan for “senior management liability”, under which executives could be prosecuted for failing to protect users, will apply only to illegal material such as child abuse and terrorism.

Companies that host “legal but harmful” material such as self-harm videos, or which allow cyberbullying, will not

Molly Russell, 14, killed herself in 2017 after viewing self-harm images on social media.
Her father, Ian Russell, said that without the threat of criminal liability the new regulatory regime would be “half-hearted”Boris Johnson has been accused of diluting plans for laws that would leave social media executives facing prosecution for failing to protect children.
The government is due to publish its response to a consultation on a proposal to regulate tech giants within the next fortnight.

title: Ministers are right to take control of abortion in Northern Ireland
text:
It is shameful that in 2021 women and girls in Northern Ireland are still being denied the same rights to abortion as women and girls across the rest of the United Kingdom. Quality healthcare is a basic human right.

I respect that this is a matter of conscience for many. I have defended the right of those in parliament who passionately disagree with me to not be shouted down. However, the law changed in Northern Ireland a year ago and it is unfathomable that we would stand by and allow it to be ignored. Women and girls in Northern Ireland must not be treated as second-class citizens.

Sponsored

That is why I was pleased that yesterday the government took a further step to ensure women and

title: RAF Lossiemouth serviceman asked woman to film herself as she sat on babies
text:
Dundee sheriff court was told the videos showed children extremely distressed and trying to escape from underneath her

An RAF serviceman posed as a stuntman and film-maker to persuade a woman to video herself sitting on babies for his sexual gratification.

Andrew Kerr, 35, told the woman he met on Facebook that she would be paid more for the most bizarre and cruel videos. She sent him seven videos.

Sponsored

Kerr tried to incite a second woman to carry out the same acts on young children and had sexual images of children on devices at RAF bases.

Eilidh Robertson, the fiscal depute, told Dundee sheriff court that the videos showed the 16-month-old infants “extremely distressed, crying out, and attempting to escape from underneath her”. She said: “At the time [Kerr] was employed by the RAF and was discharged in November 2019 as a result

title: A year in the life of the Sussexes: from Megxit to sharing the love in a podcast
text:
After a year of global grimness, Harry and Meghan have swept into our lives to offer comfort and solace. Their new podcast features Meghan telling us that love always wins, Harry urging us to “grab a cosy beverage” and Archie uttering his first words in public. It was this time last year that the royal family first reached for the smelling salts over Harry and Meghan. They might want to keep them to hand.

“We intend to step back as ‘senior’ members of the royal family,” the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced last January, “and work to become financially independent, while continuing to fully support Her Majesty the Queen.” They intended, they added, “to carve out a progressive new role within this
summary:

title: Police failings left Rotherham predator Arshid Hussain free to abuse girls
text:
Multiple failings left a violent predator free to target, groom and sexually abuse vulnerable children in Rotherham, a report by the police watchdog has found.

South Yorkshire police knew in 2000 that Arshid Hussain had “a number of relationships with young girls in foster care”. The force took no action against him until one of his child victims, Sammy Woodhouse, told her story to The Times in 2013.

Sponsored

Her account, using the pseudonym Jessica, triggered the inquiry that exposed the town’s child exploitation scandal, finding that 1,400 girls suffered appalling abuse by groups of men who were “almost all” of Pakistani heritage.

Hussain, 45, was jailed for 35 years in 2016 for 23 offences against nine girls including Ms Woodhouse. The judge said his victims
summary:
Multiple failings left a violent predator free to target, groom and sexually abuse vulnerable children in Rotherham, a report by the police watchdog has found.
South Yorkshire police knew in 2000 that Arshid Hussain had “a number of relationships with young girls in foster care”.
The force took no action against him until one of his child victims, Sammy Woodhouse, told her story to The Times in 2013.

title: It was quite good to see a referee stand up for himself for a change
text:
Last month Darren Drysdale finally snapped. The referee locked heads with Alan Judge after suffering abuse from the Ipswich Town midfielder that Drysdale described as “the worst he had experienced” at a disciplinary hearing last week. The language in the rest of his statement is too strong to write here, so I’ll substitute the swear words for innocent ones, like my grandma would.

Drysdale said his act of aggression came after he blew his whistle and Judge charged towards him screaming: “It’s a ducking penalty you cheating bald currant.” He did well not to headbutt him, like my grandma would.

Sponsored

It’s a wonder this doesn’t happen more often given what referees have to put up with. As a child, all your friends make fun of

title: Rape and a drugs death as 6,000 go to illegal parties
text:
A 20-year-old man died of a suspected drug overdose, a woman was raped and three people were stabbed during two illegal raves that attracted more than 6,000 people in Greater Manchester.

The 20-year-old man, who is thought to have died of a drug overdose, had attended a gathering of about 4,000 people at Daisy Nook Country Park in Droylsden, Greater Manchester police said. There were no further reported criminal incidents.

Sponsored

At the other rave, in Carrington, an 18-year-old woman was raped and men aged 18, 25 and 26 were hurt in separate stabbings. A 25-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

title: Psychotherapist Philippa Perry on lockdown, love and her marriage to Grayson
text:
I was supposed to meet Philippa Perry at her house in Islington, but by a stroke of luck I got ill, so we had to reschedule for a date when she’d be at her cottage on the South Downs. By the time I reach her door at the end of a winding country track dotted with sheep and cattle grids, nestled in rolling hills, the relocation feels so serendipitous I half wonder if my subconscious might have engineered the illness just to bring me to this idyll.

It’s a ridiculous thought of course, but in the company of a celebrated psychotherapist you can’t help but start thinking about how the mind works. While I’m taking off my coat Perry is already talking about countertransference. The
summary:
I was supposed to meet Philippa Perry at her house in Islington, but by a stroke of luck I got ill, so we had to reschedule for a date when she’d be at her cottage on the South Downs.
By the time I reach her door at the end of a winding country track dotted with sheep and cattle grids, nestled in rolling hills, the relocation feels so serendipitous I half wonder if my subconscious might have engineered the illness just to bring me to this idyll.
It’s a ridiculous thought of course, but in the company of a celebrated psychotherapist you can’t help but start thinking about how the mind works.
While I’m taking off my coat Perry is already talking about countertransference.

title: Pope claims gossip is worse than coronavirus
text:
The Pope repeated his frequent complaint about the “plague” of gossip in his weekly blessing

The Pope has said that gossip is a “plague worse than Covid” that he believes is seeking to divide the Roman Catholic church.

He strayed from his prepared text in his weekly blessing yesterday to reiterate his frequent complaint about slander within church communities and the Vatican bureaucracy.

Sponsored

Without citing examples, he continued at some length to say that the devil was the “biggest gossiper” and was seeking to split the church with lies.

Francis, 83, said: “Please brothers and sisters, let’s try to not gossip. Gossip is a plague worse than Covid. Worse. Let’s make a big effort: no gossiping!”

The Pope was elaborating on a gospel passage about the need to correct others privately when they do something wrong.

The Catholic hierarchy has
summary:

He strayed from his prepared text in his weekly blessing yesterday to reiterate his frequent complaint about slander within church communities and the Vatican bureaucracy.

Gossip is a plague worse than Covid.
Let’s make a big effort: no gossiping!”The Pope was elaborating on a gospel passage about the need to correct others privately when they do something wrong.

title: MPs must back the genocide amendment to oppose the oppression of the Uighurs
text:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”. As well as the more obvious acts of killing and causing serious harm, the list includes preventing births, forcibly removing children and “deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part”.

These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy. This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes. But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.

Sponsored

Is what is happening to the Uighur people in China a genocide? Let us look at
summary:
In the 1948 Genocide Convention, genocide is defined as five prohibited acts committed with the intention of destroying a group of people “in whole or in part”.
These acts must be carried out with the intention to destroy.
This is what distinguishes genocide from other international crimes.
But few genocidal regimes leave a paper trail detailing their genocidal intentions, and so intent can be inferred from actions.
SponsoredIs what is happening to the Uighur people in China a genocide?

title: Calls for state inspection of private schools after abuse scandals
text:
Pupils protest this week at Highgate School in north London, which was the subject of a dossier containing 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape

Private school inspections should be overhauled after a series of sexual abuse and harassment scandals, the chairman of the education select committee has said.

Robert Halfon made the comments in response to allegations of abuse across the private school sector. Highgate School, which was the subject of a dossier featuring 220 testimonies of peer-on-peer sexual harassment and rape, has appointed Dame Anne Rafferty, a former Court of Appeal judge, to lead an independent review. Meanwhile, Dulwich College was said to have threatened pupils with disciplinary action if they joined a planned protest yesterday after some students were reported to police over allegations of sexual harassment.

title: Herbert Kretzmer obituary
text:
Herbie Kretzmer did not so much translate Les Misérables as create an English-language version of an obscure French musical that in 1980 had played for a few months in Paris. In the process he read Victor Hugo’s novel in English and worked from a literal translation of Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg’s original script.

“You cannot translate a song,” he explained. “You can translate a textbook and even a novel, but a song is no more than a compendium of nuances and references and illusions, with a resonance within a particular culture. So simply to translate the words into their dictionary meaning isn’t going to work.”

Sponsored

He cited I Dreamed a Dream, where the literal translation is: “I had dreamed of another life/ In
summary:

title: Escape to the Suffolk countryside
text:
It’s good to be free again, isn’t it? Even partially. I was giddy leaving the capital for Suffolk last weekend. Fresh air! The sea! Fish and chips! Better still — a pub garden that we didn’t have to book ahead. These days that’s enough to make you feel as if you’ve won the lottery.

We caught the last of the sunshine at the King’s Head in Laxfield, which is better known as the Low House, a 16th-century thatched pub run as a co-operative behind the village church. To my husband Rob’s delight, our (admittedly modest) round cost £3.50.

Sponsored

Yes it got chilly but, luckily, we had a fire pit to get back to — another frequent scorer in pandemic bingo — at Blyth Rise Stays,

title: Emirates lift Sharia to allow alcohol and ban honour killings
text:
Drinking alcohol and cohabiting outside marriage are to be allowed in the United Arab Emirates after the state announced a relaxation of its strict Islamic laws.

So-called honour killings, in which men murder female relatives who are deemed to have brought shame on the family, have also been criminalised under laws that have come into immediate effect. There will also be harsher punishments for men who harass women.

Sponsored

The move is part of a long-running drive to attract western tourists and investment despite the strict Sharia-based legal system. About 8.4 million foreigners, including 250,000 Britons, live in the UAE, outnumbering locals by nine to one. Dozens have been persecuted in the past for kissing in public, homosexuality or breaking alcohol and drugs laws. More recently
summary:
Drinking alcohol and cohabiting outside marriage are to be allowed in the United Arab Emirates after the state announced a relaxation of its strict Islamic laws.
So-called honour killings, in which men murder female relatives who are deemed to have brought shame on the family, have also been criminalised under laws that have come into immediate effect.
SponsoredThe move is part of a long-running drive to attract western tourists and investment despite the strict Sharia-based legal system.

title: Letters to the Editor: Getting children back to nature
text:
Natural England’s People and Nature survey has found that children from low-income and ethnic-minority backgrounds are less likely to spend time outside (“Natural history GCSE to tempt pupils outdoors”, News, last week).

This is one of the reasons we are creating a nature recovery network, to afford every child the opportunity to play in nature-rich places near their home.

Sponsored

My first job in conservation in 1984 was working with schoolchildren. It led me to believe that fostering a love of nature at school can create connections that last a lifetime, and is the surest way to encourage the changes needed to restore the web of life on which we all depend.

Tony Juniper, chairman, Natural England

Wild things: the poor and ethnic minorities are missing out RICHARD DRURY

Testing ground

We welcome the spirit and ambition
summary:

This is one of the reasons we are creating a nature recovery network, to afford every child the opportunity to play in nature-rich places near their home.

title: Viggo Mortensen: Lord of the Rings hottie to director of arthouse film Falling
text:
The Lord of the Rings movie trilogy was many things for many people. For Tolkien fans it was a breathtaking adaptation. For Hollywood bean counters it was an eye-watering payday (almost $3 billion at the box office). For fantasy film nerds it was proof that silly costumes, magical powers and wacky creatures could dominate the multiplex (it paved the way for Marvel’s ascendancy). For Viggo Mortensen, who played the trilogy’s sword-wielding hero Aragorn over 14 months of principal photography in New Zealand and three subsequent years of sporadic reshoots, it was much simpler than that. It was film school.

“On a practical level, that’s what it was,” the 62-year-old Danish-American actor says today, still infuriatingly chiselled, even on a blurry Zoom link from his home
summary:
The Lord of the Rings movie trilogy was many things for many people.
For Hollywood bean counters it was an eye-watering payday (almost $3 billion at the box office).
For fantasy film nerds it was proof that silly costumes, magical powers and wacky creatures could dominate the multiplex (it paved the way for Marvel’s ascendancy).

title: Lord Lester of Herne Hill, human rights lawyer who quit Lords in sex scandal, dies at 84
text:
Lord Lester was an influential human rights lawyer before resigning from the House of Lords after being accused of sexual harassment

Lord Lester of Herne Hill, the lawyer who played a crucial role in enacting race and sex discrimination laws in the UK, as well as pressing for human rights legislation, has died aged 84.

In 2018 he resigned from the House of Lords amid allegations that he had sexually harassed a woman campaigning against forced marriage.

Sponsored

The QC was affiliated first with the Labour Party, then the SDP, before becoming a Liberal Democrat peer in 1993. But at the end of 2018 the Lords confirmed an earlier finding that the peer had breached the House’s code of conduct by sexually harassing a lobbyist 12 years earlier.

The peers agreed a report from the Lords privileges and conduct committee into the allegations made by Jasvinder Sanghera
summary:
Lord Lester was an influential human rights lawyer before resigning from the House of Lords after being accused of sexual harassmentLord Lester of Herne Hill, the lawyer who played a crucial role in enacting race and sex discrimination laws in the UK, as well as pressing for human rights legislation, has died aged 84.
In 2018 he resigned from the House of Lords amid allegations that he had sexually harassed a woman campaigning against forced marriage.
SponsoredThe QC was affiliated first with the Labour Party, then the SDP, before becoming a Liberal Democrat peer in 1993.

title: Court orders to stop domestic abuse soared in lockdown
text:
Domestic violence in the country’s first lockdown led to a record number of people using the courts to protect themselves from abusers, new figures show.

More than 8,800 applications for domestic violence remedy orders were made in England and Wales between April and June 2020, the highest number ever recorded by the Ministry of Justice in a quarter. The figure was 24% higher than the same quarter last year.

Sponsored

The sharp rise has been attributed to the “pressure cooker” effect of lockdown, trapping victims at home. A Women’s Aid survey found that more than 60% of those living with an abuser reported that their predicament got worse during the pandemic.

Lisa King, communications director of Refuge, said: “The very sad fact of the matter is

title: German paedophile is new suspect in Madeleine McCann case
text:
Madeleine McCann was three when she was abducted from her family’s holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in 2007

A German paedophile was identified last night as the key suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann in the most significant breakthrough in the inquiry since she vanished 13 years ago.

The serving prisoner is thought to have been in the Algarve resort where Madeleine was abducted from her bed shortly before her fourth birthday in May 2007. He is alleged to have discussed her disappearance in an internet chatroom.

Sponsored

German police said that they were investigating the murder of Madeleine and described the 43-year-old suspect as a “multiple criminal sex offender, who has also been convicted of child sexual abuse”.

He is believed to have burgled hotel and holiday rental properties and trafficked drugs while living in the Algarve between 1995 and 2007.

Christian

He is alleged to have discussed her disappearance in an internet chatroom.

title: Amy Coney Barrett: Catholic rightwinger ‘is Trump’s choice for Supreme Court’
text:
Amy Coney Barrett, if confirmed, will join Mr Trump’s two other appointments to swing the nine-member court 6-3 to the right

A Catholic mother-of-seven is tipped to be President Trump’s choice to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the liberal Supreme Court judge who yesterday became the first woman and the first Jewish person to lie in state in the US Capitol.

Amy Coney Barrett, 48, has been pushed hard by the Christian right after Mr Trump decided to speed ahead with the appointment before the election. He is due to name his candidate this evening.

Mrs Barrett’s children include one who has Down’s syndrome, contributing to conservatives’ belief that she will support restrictive rulings on abortion in cases pushed by anti-abortion campaigners. They aim ultimately to overturn Roe v Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that guaranteed women’s right to choose an abortion.

title: The best new thrillers for February 2021 — kidnap, murder, revenge and cold cases
text:
Following the traumatic events of the novel that first introduced her, The Fragility of Bodies, the Argentine investigative journalist Veronica Rosenthal takes off upcountry for a holiday. She falls in with two European girls and finds herself seduced by one of them. But at a party to which she brings the pair, they disappear and are later found murdered.

Sponsored

A black magic ritual is blamed. However, Veronica begins to uncover previous killings of local women dating back decades that have gone unpunished, as all the while she is dogged by an assassin bent on revenge. With its social concerns, The Foreign Girls is very much a literary novel rather than simply a thriller. It largely overcomes the difficulties of being translated from another language
summary:
Following the traumatic events of the novel that first introduced her, The Fragility of Bodies, the Argentine investigative journalist Veronica Rosenthal takes off upcountry for a holiday.
She falls in with two European girls and finds herself seduced by one of them.
But at a party to which she brings the pair, they disappear and are later found murdered.
However, Veronica begins to uncover previous killings of local women dating back decades that have gone unpunished, as all the while she is dogged by an assassin bent on revenge.
With its social concerns, The Foreign Girls is very much a literary novel rather than simply a thriller.

title: Extradited QC John Watt due in court on child sex abuse charges
text:
On his flight to Glasgow John Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers

A senior Scottish lawyer has been extradited from the United States to face charges of historical child sex abuse.

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of attacking four children in the 1970s and 1980s. Among his accusers is Susan Henderson, whose claims of a paedophile ring in the Scottish legal world led to a high-profile police inquiry.

Sponsored

Mr Watt, 71, was flown from the US to his native Scotland on Friday. He spent the weekend in police cells before a scheduled appearance at Edinburgh sheriff court this morning.

On his flight to Glasgow Mr Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers who had travelled to New York last week. He had been transferred there from Oklahoma, where he lived and was arrested
summary:

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of attacking four children in the 1970s and 1980s.

He spent the weekend in police cells before a scheduled appearance at Edinburgh sheriff court this morning.
On his flight to Glasgow Mr Watt was escorted by three Police Scotland officers who had travelled to New York last week.

title: Sex abuse in Scottish football: Rangers apologise to victims
text:
The club’s statement comes after a review commissioned by the SFA ordered clubs to make an “unequivocal and unreserved” apology to survivors of abuse

Rangers FC has apologised to all victims of abuse “within Scottish football” weeks after being urged to do so by authors of an official report into sexual misconduct against children.

An independent review commissioned by the Scottish FA ordered clubs who had failed to protect young players to offer an “unequivocal and unreserved” apology to survivors.

Sponsored

The report, published last month, unmasked Gordon Neely, Rangers’ former head of youth development, as a prolific paedophile.

It found he had sexually assaulted at least three teenagers at Ibrox before being sacked in 1991.

Neely had molested other young players at Hibernian and Hutchison Vale, an Edinburgh youth side, before joining Rangers in 1986.

The Scottish FA, Motherwell, Hibernian, Falkirk, Partick Thistle, the Highland league club Forres

title: Italy’s mafia trial of the century
text:
From left: the special courtroom in Lamezia Terme, Calabria, on January 13, the opening day of the trial; Cinquefrondi in Calabria

Italy’s biggest mafia trial in 30 years got off to a deceptively low-key start in Calabria last month as hundreds of lawyers filed into a converted call centre on an industrial estate to defend 355 ’NDrangheta syndicate suspects. Covid restrictions on travel meant the cages set up to hold the accused were empty. Instead, video screens hanging from the ceiling of the huge room lit up as defendants stuck in jails across Italy were patched in for a very unusual Zoom conference.

As is customary on the first day of big Italian trials, no evidence was heard as judges and lawyers discussed court procedures, and by mid-afternoon bored journalists were taking shelter from the rain outside, smoking and knocking back espressos served at the makeshift

title: Delay to Scottish child abuse inquiry was no whitewash, ex-leader says
text:
Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale said decisions made about abuse survivors was to make sure officials did the right thing

Ministers were not trying to “cover things up” when they resisted calls for an inquiry into the physical and sexual abuse of children in care, a former first minister, has said.

Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale, who was in office from 2001 to 2007, told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry that any decisions taken were “trying to do the right things by survivors, and by those who might go into care in the future”.

Sponsored

He said: “The core decision was about trying to do the right thing — not to impress the public, or the parliament, or to cover things up. I think the majority of people involved were trying to achieve the right outcome.”

The latest phase of the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry, heard before

title: This month in the Times photographic archive: February 2021
text:
Valentine’s Day proved to be a socially distanced affair this year with national Covid-19 restrictions still in place. We uncovered some amusing and emotive images as we searched our archives for images themed around love and public displays of affection.

In 1983 Sally Soames was en route to photograph imagery of the impending general election when she encountered young lovers on the platform at Bournemouth train station. The ingenuity of the press photographer once more on display, camera in hand, documenting anything that catches her eye. In this case, a snatched few frames of lovers embracing. By the time she clicks the shutter on the last frame she appears to have attracted the attention of the youngsters. Similarly, Allan Ballard was in Margate photographing a

The ingenuity of the press photographer once more on display, camera in hand, documenting anything that catches her eye.
By the time she clicks the shutter on the last frame she appears to have attracted the attention of the youngsters.

title: Labour must do more to deal with the antisemitism that drove me out
text:
A year ago, I did the unthinkable. I resigned from the Labour Party after 55 years as a member and 50 years as an elected representative, driven out by the ugly antisemitism that became normalised with the entry of the far-left following the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader.

The change in Liverpool Riverside, then my constituency, was speedy and traumatic. Membership increased from 500 to 2,700. The atmosphere in the regular meetings became deeply unpleasant. It was made clear that I was the target and I was to be removed.

title: Gillian Bowditch: Students are forgotten victims of the pandemic
text:
You wouldn’t know it from their TikTok, which is still packed with the usual goofy nonsense but the neglected cohort of this pandemic are university students, who are now heading into exam season with as much support as a one-legged tightrope walker.

In the great Covid-19 largesse-meets-election-freebie munificence, in which everything from laptops for school kids to free bikes have been promised, students have been largely left to fend for themselves. The more prestigious the establishment, the worse it seems to be.

Sponsored

School pupils north and south of the border will not sit exams this year and while that brings its own problems, some of the immediate pressure has been removed. The same empathy has been extended to many college students.

title: Joe Biden moves to tackle America’s gun ‘epidemic’
text:
President Biden waded into one of the most contentious issues in American politics yesterday by announcing new measures to stem gun violence.

Speaking in the White House Rose Garden to an audience that included those who had lost loved ones in mass shootings in recent years, Biden, 78, denounced members of Congress for offering plenty of thoughts and prayers but little in the way of concrete action to stop the deaths of hundreds of people. “Gun violence in this country is an epidemic,” he said to applause. “And it’s an international embarrassment.”

Sponsored

He thanked those who had the courage to campaign on the issue and “to turn pain into purpose and demand that we take the action that gives meaning to the word ‘enough’”. He

title: What’s on TV and radio tonight: Tuesday, March 2
text:
Viewing guide, by Ben Dowell

Your Honor

Sky Atlantic/Now TV, 9pm

Bryan Cranston is probably best known for the superb drama Breaking Bad in which he played a cancer-stricken chemistry teacher who turns to drug production partly out of a twisted sense of reclaiming his male pride. This drama by the British writer Peter Moffat is in a vaguely similar vein, only Cranston this time plays a gentle and liberal New Orleans judge called Michael Desiato. title: Tusla: Child protection agency needs legal backing, says report
text:
The special rapporteur on child protection highlighted gaps in the Child Care Act covering the nature of Tusla’s obligation to investigate complaints

Tusla should have an “express obligation” under law to receive, assess and investigate complaints of child sexual abuse, a report has said.

The annual report of the special rapporteur on child protection, published yesterday, found that the Child Care Act 1991 did not provide a “sufficiently robust legal basis” for the work of Tusla, the state’s child protection agency.

Sponsored

Under the Act, Tusla needs only to: “Take such steps as it considers requisite to identify children who are not receiving adequate care and protection and coordinate information from all relevant sources relating to children in its area.”

The report says: “[The Act] contains no detail about the nature of Tusla’s obligation to investigate complaints; about the procedural requirements that such an investigation should adhere
summary:

title: Freeze Chinese oppressors’ dirty money and assets in UK
text:
Disney’s new Mulan film brings into focus again the Chinese government’s brutal repression of the Uighur population in Xinjiang. The end credits of the new film give thanks to different government entities from the province despite detailed reports of more than one million people being kept in so-called re-education camps there.

Included in those thanked is the public security bureau in the city of Turpan, which experts have suggested is the body primarily tasked with running the internment camps. This is no small thing. Reports from the camps are horrific, detailing physical abuse, squalid conditions, and forced denouncement of religion. Forced sterilisations and abortions have also been reported, with human rights groups likening the situation to genocide.

Forced sterilisations and abortions have also been reported, with human rights groups likening the situation to genocide.

title: Pupils at Fornethy House for sick girls ‘abused and made to eat vomit’
text:
Police are investigating the claims of historical abuse at the institution in Angus

Police are investigating allegations of historical physical and sexual abuse at a Scottish residential school for ill girls.

Victims told how they were regularly attacked by staff at Fornethy House, which was run by Glasgow’s local authority in Kilry, Angus, after being told they were going to a holiday camp.

Sponsored

Sick children as young as five would be taken to the school 90 miles from the city for “convalescent” breaks after it opened in 1961. Forty former pupils, now aged between their forties and their sixties, have come forward to claim they were force-fed, made to eat vomit and ordered to walk around naked.

Marion Reid, 63, was sent to the school with her older sister and claims to have been frequently punched and slapped
summary:
Police are investigating the claims of historical abuse at the institution in AngusPolice are investigating allegations of historical physical and sexual abuse at a Scottish residential school for ill girls.

title: Mary Astell: pioneering feminist’s library unearthed at Cambridge University
text:
Catherine Sutherland, deputy librarian at Magdalene College, with the collection that she discovered

Almost 50 books and pamphlets that belonged to the writer and philosopher often regarded as “the first English feminist” have been found in the library of a Cambridge University college.

Copious annotations in the 47 works in English, French and Latin reveal how Mary Astell, who lived from 1666 to 1731, engaged with politics, religion and complex natural philosophy, such as the ideas of René Descartes.

Sponsored

Astell was a proponent of women’s education who railed against the “unjust” monopolising of learning by men. The works were identified by Catherine Sutherland, deputy librarian at Magdalene College, based on handwriting comparisons and other clues.

Mary Astell urged the education of women ALAMY

title: Facebook moderators speak of Covid risk in Dublin office
text:
Sheryl Sandberg gives a glossy image of Facebook, but its Covalen contractors say they are not treated as well as staff

Contract staff working as moderators for Facebook in Dublin have complained about the conditions in their Sandyford office, after two people went down with the coronavirus.

Message boards seen by The Sunday Times show that workers engaged by Covalen in the Nova Atria building are unhappy about the working conditions imposed on them. Covalen is owned by the CPL group.

Sponsored

The moderators, most of whom earn less than €30,000 a year, have complained about being required to be present in the office; about the difficulties of social distancing with so many co-workers; and about the office staying open after two people tested positive for Covid.

The staff were sent home to work at the end of March but were told to return to the office

title: The ripple effect of Where Is George Gibney?
text:
The success of the podcast has led to abuse complaints being made to gardai by two former Olympic swimmers

More than 25 years after he eluded charges of raping and sexually abusing children and fled to America, the story of one of Ireland’s most notorious fugitives from justice has gone global.

The 10-part BBC Sounds podcast Where Is George Gibney?, about Ireland’s former national and Olympic swimming coach, has been downloaded more than a million times. It has been this country’s most listened-to podcast since August, while drawing audiences in 160 other nations, including the UK, America, Australia, Canada, Singapore and across Europe. Such is its success, the BBC is simultaneously broadcasting the series on Radio5 Live on Saturday nights.

It’s possible that Gibney, seated, will be extradited to face new charges

text:
Ian Wright had to face the wall when Match of the Day, his favourite show, came on television

Generations of fans associate the Match of the Day theme tune with weekends on the sofa enjoying the football highlights.

For one of its pundits, however, the music has deeply disturbing associations. Ian Wright, the former England and Arsenal striker, has revealed that the BBC show’s soundtrack awakens memories of the “Guantanamo Bay-style” abuse he suffered at the hands of his violent stepfather.

Wright opens up about his traumatic childhood and his struggle to cope with its legacy in Home Truths, a BBC documentary about domestic violence.

title: Office romances: ‘A late night drink ended with sex at his flat’
text:
Office romance — a good way to meet your partner or doomed to end in failure and embarrassment?

Damian Whitworth, writer

Back in the days before email, shortly after The Times’s correspondents stopped sending dispatches via pigeon post, we used to communicate by an internal computer messaging system. One day I saw “message pending” on my screen and opened it with a greater than normal sense of anticipation.

Sponsored

The message was from one of the paper’s sharpest investigative reporters, who also happened to be the building’s most outrageous gossip. This should be good, I thought. The note was simple and jolting. “I know all about you and M,” it said. Our office romance was no longer secret.

He was a friend, so I pleaded for discretion, but confirming the truth to him was as good as doing so to the Press Association.
summary:
Office romance — a good way to meet your partner or doomed to end in failure and embarrassment?
Damian Whitworth, writerBack in the days before email, shortly after The Times’s correspondents stopped sending dispatches via pigeon post, we used to communicate by an internal computer messaging system.
One day I saw “message pending” on my screen and opened it with a greater than normal sense of anticipation.
SponsoredThe message was from one of the paper’s sharpest investigative reporters, who also happened to be the building’s most outrageous gossip.
Our office romance was no longer secret.

Liberals, and Muslims such as Baroness Warsi, do society a disservice when they place a fear of offence before tolerance for diversity of thought. It is an unhealthy and dangerous exchange.

Soraya Gray, London W6

Tolerating those who worship fictional deities is fair enough, but devotees should do their thing within the law, quietly respecting the many of us who have no interest in religion.

title: Scottish students add rape claims to website
text:
Current and former pupils at Scottish universities have reportedly been encouraged to come forward following the death of Sarah Everard in south London

Claims of rape on Scottish university campuses are among thousands being posted on a website for survivors of sexual abuse.

Everyone’s Invited, a website and social media account for students and former students to share experiences of sexual assault and harassment anonymously has been inundated in recent weeks. People have apparently been inspired to come forward after the death of Sarah Everard, who went missing in south London.

Sponsored

Almost 5,200 accounts have been posted. They include alleged sex attacks at Edinburgh and Glasgow universities. One testimony describes a rape by “a boy in my block” during a first term at Edinburgh’s Pollock halls of residence: “I still see him around sometimes and it triggers huge anxiety in me, I’m sure he has no idea of
summary:

title: Child rapist Aaron McWilliams used Gumtree ads to get jobs as nanny
text:
One of the UK’s most “devious” paedophiles was able to perpetrate five years of child sex abuse after advertising his services as a male nanny on Gumtree and social media sites.

Aaron McWilliams, 28, raped or molested at least 24 children, including a four-month-old baby, after parents hired him unwittingly. Detectives at Scotland Yard found he had duped families across the country and as far afield as Italy and Germany, sometimes by providing forged references.

title: Coventry cult leader Rajinder Kalia accused of raping devotees
text:
Worshippers are allegedly indoctrinated to believe Rajinder Kalia is “an incarnation of God and or the divine”

A guru who claimed he was God on Earth has been accused of raping four devotees, according to court documents that appear to reveal an undetected cult in Coventry.

Rajinder Kalia is accused of exerting “undue influence” over young girls for three decades and allegedly using Baba Balak Nath, an obscure branch of Hinduism, for his own nefarious purposes.

Sponsored

Kalia, 65, is alleged to have groomed worshippers as young as four at the temple in Bell Green, Coventry, where devotees see him as “all-powerful, all-seeing and all-knowing” and are allegedly indoctrinated to believe he is “an incarnation of God and or the divine”.

Kalia was photographed wearing a crown and depicted as a deity in paintings

title: Doctors paid thousands for mother and baby home trials
text:
Both Wellcome and Glaxo were subsumed into GlaxoSmithKline in 2000

Two doctors who blocked a state inquiry into vaccine trials they conducted on hundreds of children in mother and baby homes received personal cheques from the British pharmaceutical companies involved, last week’s report on the institutions shows.

Two other doctors who ran vaccine and baby-milk trials in homes in Dublin and Cork were offered money and a free flight for a holiday in England.

Sponsored

Patrick Meenan, a former president of the Medical Council of Ireland, and Irene Hillary, who led the National Virus Reference Laboratory in University College Dublin (UCD), made successful court challenges after being called as witnesses to the Laffoy Commission on child abuse in residential institutions. As a result, its investigation of vaccine trials for Glaxo Laboratories and the Wellcome Foundation between

title: Hardline Hindus force interfaith Indian TV ad off air
text:
Hindu nationalists have forced the withdrawal of a TV advert showing an interfaith couple celebrating the upcoming birth of their child, the latest intensification of the culture war in India.

The commercial was intended as a celebration of tolerance and diversity but instead provoked a furious reaction for showing a Hindu woman arriving at a baby shower thrown by her Muslim in-laws. As the two families and faiths join in celebration of the unborn child the narrator asks, “What can’t we achieve, if we are united?”

Sponsored

Nationalists vehemently disagreed, with right-wing Hindus quickly calling for a boycott of the company, Tanishq, a jewellery brand. There were demonstrations outside some of its shops, with critics saying the advert legitimised “love jihad”, a conspiracy that says Muslim
summary:

title: Times letters: noise pollution and the lockdown’s respite
text:
Sir, The fine article by Jenni Russell (“We can’t go back to our old noisy world”, May 21) highlights the problems of noise but also possible solutions. Many of the latter cost little but have never been implemented. It costs nothing to reduce the number and volume of announcements on public transport; lowering speed limits is not a matter of cost but of political will; cycle lanes are among the cheapest pieces of transport infrastructure to build. Even aircraft noise can be tackled by rotating flight paths. The challenge now is for national and local government and the transport operators to seize this moment to put in place low-cost solutions to ensure that we do not return to our old noisy world.

John Stewart

Sponsored
summary:
Sir, The fine article by Jenni Russell (“We can’t go back to our old noisy world”, May 21) highlights the problems of noise but also possible solutions.
Many of the latter cost little but have never been implemented.
Even aircraft noise can be tackled by rotating flight paths.
The challenge now is for national and local government and the transport operators to seize this moment to put in place low-cost solutions to ensure that we do not return to our old noisy world.

text:

title: Louis De Zoysa: Suspect in murder of Sergeant Matt Ratana named
text:
Louis De Zoysa, the suspect, was “very serious”, according to a friend

The person accused of shooting dead a custody sergeant inside a police station is a reclusive young autistic man from a middle-class family.

Louis De Zoysa, 23, is in a critical condition in hospital after allegedly killing Sergeant Matiu Ratana inside Croydon custody suite in south London early last Friday.

Sponsored

A man suspected of supplying Mr De Zoysa with the revolver used in the murder was arrested in Norwich early yesterday morning as the police investigation intensified.

Officers blew the doors off a former Second World War bomb storage unit on a Surrey farm as they swooped on new locations connected to the suspect.

Police cordoned off the area where Mr De Zoysa was arrested before allegedly killing Sergeant Matiu Ratana GRANT FALVEY/LNP

Mr De Zoysa was arrested close to his family home at about 1.30am on Friday and taken to the police station
summary:

title: Britain may seek Republic’s help to tackle sectarian violence in Northern Ireland
text:
Dozens of police have been hurt in riots that started in loyalist areas

Downing Street is considering intergovernmental talks over rising tensions in Northern Ireland despite concerns that involving Dublin would further inflame unionist anger.

Boris Johnson has not ruled out travelling to the province if the disorder continues but any visit might be delayed until the official mourning period for the Duke of Edinburgh has concluded.

Sponsored

It comes amid increasing concern in government at the spectre of sectarian violence after more rioting on Friday led to 14 officers being injured.

Mary McAleese, the former president of Ireland, said yesterday that young people were still being “taught to hate”. Northern Ireland’s children’s commissioner said that adults coercing and encouraging young people to commit violence was tantamount to child abuse.

The province has experienced the worst unrest in 16

title: Social media sites face £18m fine over child users
text:
Molly Russell‘s father has campaigned for social media reform since his daughter’s death in 2017

Social media companies face huge fines if they fail to stop children using their services under new proposals.

The government has told tech firms they will need to find much more effective ways to stop children accessing their platforms, other than just asking for a date of birth.

Sponsored

Most social media sites say their services are for people aged at least 13. UK and US law prohibits websites and apps from collecting personal data of anyone under 13 without parental consent.

A survey showed that about 60 per cent of eight-year-olds and 90 per cent of 12-year-olds in England say they use private messaging services that have a minimum age limit of 13.

title: Murderer of backpacker Karen Aim in New Zealand may be freed
text:
Karen Aim was alive when she was found but died of brain injuries shortly afterwards

A man who murdered a Scottish backpacker and became the youngest person in the history of New Zealand to receive a life sentence may be granted parole this week.

Jahche Broughton was 14 when he beat Karen Aim, from Orkney, to death with a baseball bat in the North Island resort of Taupo as she was walking home after an evening out with friends. Ms Aim, 26, who had been on a working holiday, was alive when she was found but died of brain injuries shortly afterwards.

title: Ethiopian fugitives to leave Italy’s embassy after 30 years
text:
Two former leaders of Ethiopia’s Mengistu regime are preparing to end their 30-year stay as self-invited “guests” at Italy’s embassy in Addis Ababa after their death sentences were commuted.

Berhanu Bayeh, 82, a former foreign minister and Marxist ideologue, and Addis Tedla, 74, a former chief of the general staff, were among a group who sought refuge in the embassy in May 1991 as the military dictatorship of Mengistu Haile Mariam was overthrown.

Sponsored

The men were sentenced to death for complicity in the crimes of the USSR-backed regime, which is accused of killing up to two million Ethiopians during its 14-year rule.

Mengistu, 83, who lives in Zimbabwe, was one of a group of military officers who overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie in 1974. He consolidated

title: Colet Court: Sex-charge prep teacher found dead
text:
Tim Harbord resigned from Colet Court in 2013 after concerns were raised about his conduct

A former teacher at one of Britain’s leading preparatory schools has died shortly after being charged with a historical sex offence.

Tim Harbord spent 25 years at Colet Court, the junior division of St Paul’s School, in Barnes, southwest London. He resigned after concern was raised in 2013 about his closeness to a pupil. It later emerged that a complaint against him had been made as early as 1990 but no action was taken.

Sponsored

Mr Harbord, 67, was arrested in 2013 on suspicion of the sexual grooming of a child. A year later he was again arrested and questioned about the alleged sexual assault of a child.

The second arrest was part of Operation Winthorpe, a police inquiry launched after The Times revealed multiple allegations
summary:

title: EU offers Erdogan more money to halt migrant surge from Turkey
text:
President Erdogan has won more money from the EU in return for preventing a new refugee crisis in Europe.

Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, president of the European Council, spent three hours in “frank discussions” with the Turkish leader during a rare visit to Ankara yesterday. They agreed that a five-year-old deal under which Turkey was given €6 billion to stop the flow of migrants to Greece would be extended, with more money being provided. Exact details have yet to be made public, but an EU financing package that will help Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan to care for refugees will be announced soon.

Sponsored

The pair offered an olive branch to Erdogan after years of tense relations marked
summary:
President Erdogan has won more money from the EU in return for preventing a new refugee crisis in Europe.
Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, president of the European Council, spent three hours in “frank discussions” with the Turkish leader during a rare visit to Ankara yesterday.
They agreed that a five-year-old deal under which Turkey was given €6 billion to stop the flow of migrants to Greece would be extended, with more money being provided.
Exact details have yet to be made public, but an EU financing package that will help Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan to care for refugees will be announced soon.

title: Jury clears man accused of rape after GAA clubhouse ball
text:
After a ten-day trial at the central criminal court in Dublin the jury returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty

A man has been cleared of raping a woman after they met at a New Year’s Eve ball at a GAA clubhouse.

The 33-year-old man had denied rape at his home in Westmeath on January 1, 2017.

Sponsored

The complainant was visiting a friend and had planned to spend the night in that woman’s home after going to a ball in the local GAA clubhouse. She met the accused, who was of a similar age, and they were kissing in the clubhouse.

She told the jury that towards the end of the night she could not find her friend and her mobile phone had gone dead. She said she decided she had no other option but to accept an invitation to the man’s house.

title: Police promise Brittany Higgins they will investigate her rape in Australian parliament
text:
Brittany Higgins, a former media adviser, has made a formal complaint to the Australian Federal Police over her alleged rape

A young former government staffer who alleges that she was raped in a minister’s office at Australia’s parliament secured a police investigation today amid allegations that senior government figures covered up her assault.

Brittany Higgins claims that as a 24-year-old in 2019 she was raped by a former colleague in the office of Linda Reynolds, now Australia’s defence minister. The revelations have embarrassed the prime minister, Scott Morrison, and forced a distraught Reynolds to delay answering questions on the affair in parliament this week.

title: What I’ve learnt: Paris Hilton on building a business empire, challenging abusers — and finding love
text:
Businesswoman and socialite Paris Hilton, 40, is the great-granddaughter of the Hilton Hotels founder, Conrad Hilton. She co-starred in the 2003 reality television series The Simple Life with fellow It girl Nicole Richie. She is one of the world’s highest paid female DJs and has a multimillion-dollar beauty brand. A documentary about her life, This is Paris, was released last year on YouTube. She lives in Los Angeles with her fiancé, Carter Reum, and their eight dogs.

title: Children are finally being recognised as domestic abuse victims — now they need support
text:
Children are victims of domestic abuse, but for too long they have been labelled “witnesses” or “bystanders”. The assumption has been that unless children were in the same room when domestic abuse occurred they weren’t affected.

However, as the years have gone by our thinking has evolved to understand the multiple forms domestic abuse can take, including coercive and controlling behaviour. And for children it isn’t only about seeing or hearing domestic abuse, it’s about the impact of growing up in the toxic environment domestic abuse creates — the feeling of waking up scared, and treading on eggshells, of feeling unsafe.

Sponsored

Growing up in a household with domestic abuse normalises harmful behaviour and warps the idea of what a relationship should be. Not only does
summary:
Children are victims of domestic abuse, but for too long they have been labelled “witnesses” or “bystanders”.
The assumption has been that unless children were in the same room when domestic abuse occurred they weren’t affected.
However, as the years have gone by our thinking has evolved to understand the multiple forms domestic abuse can take, including coercive and controlling behaviour.
And for children it isn’t only about seeing or hearing domestic abuse, it’s about the impact of growing up in the toxic environment domestic abuse creates — the feeling of waking up scared, and treading on eggshells, of feeling unsafe.

title: Marina O’Loughlin reviews The Bridge Arms pub in Kent
text:
A fat, vibrating bee follows me into the Bridge Arms when I go for a sneak peek at this old pub’s interior refurb. It’s that sort of place — bees and flowers and nooks and beams, every fantasy country pub cliché made flesh. And I’m wallowing in it.

Prior to this I’ve done some other wallowing. In a puffy potato flatbread, a whisper of char from the wood grill, dotted with tiny acidulated petals of pearl onion, blobs of caramelised onion puree, tiny fresh herb leaves, suave rapeseed — so pretty, so delicate, it looks as if Tinker Bell branched out into pizza delivery. It’s under the menu’s “snacks” section but comes across as intricate and as labour-intensive as the main dishes. And — less
summary:
A fat, vibrating bee follows me into the Bridge Arms when I go for a sneak peek at this old pub’s interior refurb.
It’s that sort of place — bees and flowers and nooks and beams, every fantasy country pub cliché made flesh.
And I’m wallowing in it.
Prior to this I’ve done some other wallowing.
It’s under the menu’s “snacks” section but comes across as intricate and as labour-intensive as the main dishes.

title: Magnum photo agency in row over ‘child sex abuse images’ in archive
text:
Olivia Arthur, president of Magnum Photos, said that standards had “evolved”

One of the world’s leading photographic agencies is facing a reckoning over what it admits may be problematic material in its archive.

Magnum Photos has launched an internal review of its archive after attention was drawn to its promotion of what are alleged to be images of child sex workers.

Sponsored

Olivia Arthur, president of the 75-year-old agency, said that photography was “entering an unprecedented period of self-reflection” and that standards for what was acceptable “have evolved”.

It began the review after the photography website Fstoppers accused it of promoting sexually explicit images of children as well as featuring records of child sexual abuse.

A series of photographs documenting sex workers in Thailand in the 1980s had caused particular concern.

A series of photographs documenting sex workers in Thailand in the 1980s had caused particular concern.

title: What I went through as a pupil at Westminster School
text:
As I entered my final interview for Westminster School I was buzzing with hope. It was 2008, my interviews had gone well and I had only the head master to meet. While sitting with him and talking about my plans, it occurred to me that this wood-panelled room pre-dated my right as a woman to an education — for centuries it had exclusively schooled boys, and even now girls were admitted only to the sixth form.

That September, walking into the ancient cobblestone courtyard as a 16-year-old, I was caught between terror and elation. I’d been told that you had to be tough to succeed as a girl at Westminster. I had no idea how tough I would need to be.

Sponsored

I knew about the
summary:
As I entered my final interview for Westminster School I was buzzing with hope.
It was 2008, my interviews had gone well and I had only the head master to meet.
That September, walking into the ancient cobblestone courtyard as a 16-year-old, I was caught between terror and elation.
I’d been told that you had to be tough to succeed as a girl at Westminster.
I had no idea how tough I would need to be.

title: What’s on TV and radio tonight: Wednesday, December 16
text:
For full TV listings for the week, see thetimes.co.uk/tvplanner

Viewing guide, by Joe Clay

Sponsored

The Vanishing of Suzy Lamplugh

Channel 5, 9pm

It is one of Britain’s most infamous unsolved murders. Suzy Lamplugh, a 25-year-old estate agent, was last seen on July 28, 1986, setting off to meet a client at a property in Fulham, west London. In her office diary she recorded details of a lunchtime appointment with a “Mr Kipper” at a property in Shorrolds Road and the police investigation has centred on identifying the man. Her body has never been found. In 1994 she was officially declared dead, presumed murdered. It was as if she had vanished into thin air and in the 34 years since her disappearance the police have followed

title: Parents’ revolt grows over race lessons at top New York schools
text:
Andrew Guttman wrote a letter to Brearley School in Manhattan claiming that the school was “desecrating the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr”

The first protests were voiced in an anonymous letter decrying a new “obsessive focus on race and identity” at one of New York’s top private schools.

Then a father announced that he was pulling his daughter out of another elite school on the Upper East Side, Manhattan, saying it was “gutting” its curriculum, censoring books and teaching “the extraordinarily divisive idea that there are only, and always, two groups in this country: victims and oppressors”.

Sponsored

Now parents with children at schools all over the city have formed an alliance against the antiracism training courses adopted by many schools in response to the murder of George Floyd and the worldwide protests over racial injustice. title: What’s on TV: Friday
text:
CRITICS’ CHOICE

Portillo’s Empire Journey (C5, 9pm)

What has happened to the former Thatcherite arch-patriot? Last week, briefed by Indian historians, he lambasted the East India Company and Raj for 200 years’ exploitation and carnage. Now, again with post-colonial chroniclers as interviewees, he gives an equally damning account of Britain’s slavery-scarred rule in Jamaica, from the 1655 ousting of Spain, to the Windrush and independence 300 years later. With less than an hour to tell the story (and too much on pirates and a bizarre meeting with Rastafarians), much is omitted; but even the fiercest anti-imperialist could not wish for a more critical verdict. John Dugdale

History 101 (Netflix)

title: PC Timothy Brehmer charged with woman’s murder
text:
Timothy Brehmer with his wife, left. He has been charged with the murder of Claire Parry, right, who died on Sunday morning after suffering a brain injury

A serving police officer has been charged with murdering a woman said to have been his lover of ten years in a village pub car park.

PC Timothy Brehmer, 41, is accused of strangling Claire Parry, an NHS nurse practitioner, outside the Horns Inn in West Parley, Dorset, on Saturday.

Sponsored

Mrs Parry, also 41, was found unconscious at the scene. She died on Sunday morning. A post-mortem examination showed she died from a brain injury caused by compression of the neck.

Mr Brehmer, who lives with his wife Martha, a detective, and their nine-year-old son in the New Forest, is said to have suffered self-inflicted injuries. He was also taken to hospital before being released and charged with the murder of Mrs Parry.

The mother
summary:
Timothy Brehmer with his wife, left.
PC Timothy Brehmer, 41, is accused of strangling Claire Parry, an NHS nurse practitioner, outside the Horns Inn in West Parley, Dorset, on Saturday.

title: Eat! Perfect Thai curry recipes
text:
Curry fanatic Dan Toombs, 55, has spent two decades learning curry-house secrets and perfecting the recipes that have helped him to sell more than 250,000 books. Now he has decided to jump borders and reproduce the classic Thai takeaway and restaurant dishes he enjoys at his home in Yorkshire.

“Thai food is well known for its heat but there is much more to it than that. The recipes are a beautiful melody of sweet, sour and savoury,” he says.

He was introduced to Thai food at a young age, growing up in California, where there was a large Thai expat community.

Dan Toombs KRIS KIRKHAM

title: How accurate is The Dig? What’s true and false in Netflix’s Sutton Hoo film
text:
The Sutton Hoo excavation, which forms the central focus of the new Netflix film The Dig, produced one of this country’s most important archaeological finds. Dubbed “Britain’s Tutankhamun”, the uncovering of a 1,300-year-old ship entombed beneath a huge mound in Suffolk was breathtaking. As sensational golden treasures emerged, spectral visions of vanished royal lives — probably the Anglo-Saxon king Raedwald — were irresistible. The film is based on a novel by John Preston in which more attention is paid to excavating the characters of those doing the digging, than to the archaeology. But how much does The Dig — directed by Simon Stone — reflect the reality of Sutton Hoo?

Could you see the ship as clearly as it appeared on screen?

The first
summary:
The Sutton Hoo excavation, which forms the central focus of the new Netflix film The Dig, produced one of this country’s most important archaeological finds.
Dubbed “Britain’s Tutankhamun”, the uncovering of a 1,300-year-old ship entombed beneath a huge mound in Suffolk was breathtaking.
As sensational golden treasures emerged, spectral visions of vanished royal lives — probably the Anglo-Saxon king Raedwald — were irresistible.
But how much does The Dig — directed by Simon Stone — reflect the reality of Sutton Hoo?
Could you see the ship as clearly as it appeared on screen?

title: Muslim leaders can’t dodge the questions
text:
It is, after all, called Woman’s Hour and given that organised religion is historically no friend of womankind, Zara Mohammed, new leader of the Muslim Council of Britain (MCB), might expect tough questions. A female head of a Roman Catholic umbrella group would brace herself for a grilling on papal edicts about abortion, contraception or a ban on women priests. And doubtless 200 prominent women would not write an open letter attacking the BBC.

Yet according to Labour MPs Diane Abbott and Naz Shah, and the Tory peer Baroness Warsi among others, the presenter Emma Barnett was “strikingly hostile” in asking Mohammed about the number of female imams in Britain. It was, to be fair, a snippy exchange: Barnett refused to accept the MCB leader
summary:

text:
Lord Brittan died before he and his family including his wife were told the case had been dropped

The wife of Lord Brittan has accused Scotland Yard of a “culture of cover-up” over its botched inquiry into false rape allegations that resulted in her home being searched weeks after his death.

Lady Brittan said that the force lacked “a moral spine” after nobody lost their job or was punished over Operation Midland. Lord Brittan of Spennithorne was accused by Carl Beech, a convicted paedophile who would later be found guilty of making false allegations of rape and child abuse against public figures.

title: Britain deserves a 21st-century police force
text:
The pressures on the police are relentless. During the pandemic, they have had to enforce stringent new restrictions on civil liberties and police a wave of protests, while continuing to deal with violent crime and county lines drug dealing.

Handling all these tasks simultaneously, while seeking to retain the confidence of communities, is difficult. And the job has been growing more challenging and complicated in recent years.

Sponsored

A major independent review of policing publishes its first report today. The central message is that the pattern of crime has changed dramatically in the past 20 years and policing is struggling to keep up. A 20th-century police force cannot beat 21st-century crime. title: Would you pay £3,000 for a Michelin-starred meal at home?
text:
‘This is like Cameo, but for chefs,” says Matt, my friend, as he sits in my garden and tucks into a plate of the most sublime raw scallops with oro blanco grapefruit, garum and grated cured roe.

If you don’t know Cameo, it’s a website that went stratospheric during lockdown. It allows ordinary punters to buy personalised video greetings from a selection of celebrities, birthday messages from big stars such as Lily Allen (from £187.50), Caitlyn Jenner (a lot more pricey, from £1,875) or, if your budget stretches only to £82.50, John Bercow, the former speaker of the House of Commons.

title: Ban on naming woman who killed child will remain, Court of Appeal rules
text:
The Court of Appeal ruled that the statute was “unequivocal” and if change was required that is a matter for the Oireachtas

The Court of Appeal has rejected an application by several media outlets to be allowed to name a woman who smothered her three-year-old child to death with a pillow.

The woman was acquitted of murdering her child by reason of insanity in October last year. Before her trial began two High Court judges ordered that the deceased child should not be identified and, as a consequence, the woman could not be named as to do so would identify the dead child.

title: We must bring back British families trafficked by Isis
text:
In the statutory guidance that accompanies the Modern Slavery Act, the duty of public employees faced with a trafficking case is made clear: “The safety, protection and support of the potential victim must always be the first priority.”

Unless, it seems, the victim was trafficked by so-called Islamic State. Because unfortunately, there seems to be a blind spot when it comes to the handful of British families who were trafficked to Syria by Isis, and are now held in unstable and dangerous detention camps that are bursting at the seams.

Sponsored

In its new report, the legal NGO Reprieve describes the grim reality of the sophisticated trafficking operation employed by Isis. It tells the stories of several British women and children who were groomed and trafficked

title: If Harry can’t tell his past from his elbow, he shouldn’t enter the Commonwealth shames
text:
The statesman and philanthropist Prince Harry has released footage from a Zoom call in which he explains that the Commonwealth must face up to the past, no matter how uncomfortable that might be. As I’d always imagined the Commonwealth was a sort of club that organised a fun sports day every four years for countries that needed a nice old lady to put on their banknotes, I couldn’t imagine what terrible crimes it had committed. So I did a spot of research.

And it was like looking into the history of Stow-on-the-Wold’s jam-making society. Literally nothing has happened, which is quite an achievement, since it counts as members nearly a third of the world’s population and covers 20% of the planet’s land mass.

Sponsored

It was

Viewing guide, by Ben Dowell

My Father and Me

BBC2, 9.45pm

When the acclaimed documentary film-maker Nick Broomfield was young his photographer father, Maurice, let him have a camera of his own. He closely monitored Nick’s work and once insisted that a picture the youngster was very proud of — a miserable-looking donkey staring behind a wire fence — was a waste of film. Young Nick disagreed and it’s a story that encapsulates father and son’s intense but not always easy relationship. title: Foster care: how memory boxes help to heal fractured childhoods
text:
Trauma steals memory,” says Lemn Sissay, 53, the poet and broadcaster who grew up in the British care system. Born in Wigan to a single 22-year-old student from Ethiopia, he was put in foster care shortly after birth and placed at seven months old with foster parents, the Greenwoods, on the promise of adoption. In January 1980 they cast him out of their home at the age of 12, on the spurious notion that he didn’t love them enough. There was no fond farewell. Sissay’s foster mother, her hands held flatly by her sides, watched her “son” leave without a hug and without wanting to see him again.

“I lost everybody,” he says. He was taken to Woodfields children’s home near Wigan. All he carried
summary:
Trauma steals memory,” says Lemn Sissay, 53, the poet and broadcaster who grew up in the British care system.
Born in Wigan to a single 22-year-old student from Ethiopia, he was put in foster care shortly after birth and placed at seven months old with foster parents, the Greenwoods, on the promise of adoption.
In January 1980 they cast him out of their home at the age of 12, on the spurious notion that he didn’t love them enough.
Sissay’s foster mother, her hands held flatly by her sides, watched her “son” leave without a hug and without wanting to see him again.
He was taken to Woodfields children’s home near Wigan.

title: The world’s democracies must share Biden’s load
text:
This week’s election results have entrenched divided government and poisonous animosity at the heart of American politics. In domestic policy, gridlock seems inevitable.

Both parties will be wrestling with the legacy of Trump and Trumpism for politics. But for the rest of the world, especially the democratic world, foreign policy offers a new administration more room for manoeuvre.

title: Morrison strips Australia’s judges of protection from sexual harassment claims
text:
Australia will bring judges and politicians under sexual harassment laws as its centre right government battles a series of sex scandals which has seen it lose support among women.

Scott Morrison, the prime minister, announced wide changes aimed at empowering complainants in gender-related disputes at work, removing historic exemptions from complaints about gender discrimination provided to public servants, judges and politicians.

Sponsored

The reforms will include classifying sexual harassment as “serious misconduct” and clarify that it is a valid reason for sacking employees on public and private payrolls. While MPs and judges cannot be dismissed, the changes will open them to censure or harsher penalties for proven sexual harassment.

“Sexual harassment is unacceptable,” Morrison said. “It’s not only immoral and despicable and even criminal . .
summary:
Australia will bring judges and politicians under sexual harassment laws as its centre right government battles a series of sex scandals which has seen it lose support among women.
Scott Morrison, the prime minister, announced wide changes aimed at empowering complainants in gender-related disputes at work, removing historic exemptions from complaints about gender discrimination provided to public servants, judges and politicians.
SponsoredThe reforms will include classifying sexual harassment as “serious misconduct” and clarify that it is a valid reason for sacking employees on public and private payrolls.
While MPs and judges cannot be dismissed, the changes will open them to censure or harsher penalties for proven sexual harassment.
“Sexual harassment is unacceptable,” Morrison said.

title: MPs debating harassment claims against them is ‘slap in face’ for victims
text:
Jacob Rees-Mogg has introduced restrictions which would prevent MPs from referring to details of harassment cases but staff affected say this does not address their concerns

Victims of sexual harassment and assault have said plans to allow MPs to debate complaints against members are “retraumatising” and “a slap in the face”.

MPs will be asked to approve proposals today which will permit them to discuss serious allegations against members of the House on the floor of the Commons, despite a long-running campaign for a fully independent process. Supporters say the plan upholds an important constitutional principle that MPs should have the final word on matters that may result in the expulsion of a member.

Sponsored

Jasvinder Sanghera, a campaigner against forced marriage, had a complaint of sexual harassment upheld against Lord Lester of Herne Hill, a former Liberal Democrat peer, by the Lords conduct watchdog in 2018. He denied the allegations.

MPs will be asked to approve proposals today which will permit them to discuss serious allegations against members of the House on the floor of the Commons, despite a long-running campaign for a fully independent process.
Supporters say the plan upholds an important constitutional principle that MPs should have the final word on matters that may result in the expulsion of a member.

title: Retired headmaster Arthur Hutchinson filmed himself raping sedated girl
text:
Arthur Hutchinson first abused the girl in Thailand when she was eight

A former head teacher who filmed himself raping and abusing a girl during almost a decade of sexual assault has been jailed for nine years.

Arthur Hutchinson, 74, moved to Thailand after retiring and there began to molest the child when she was eight. The abuse escalated into repeated rapes. On some occasions the girl was unconscious after he used a cloth soaked in lighter fuel to sedate her.

He amassed a collection of photographs and more than 50 hours of videos showing the abuse, which were found by police on his computer after she moved to Scotland for university. title: ‘Safeguarding’ used to be the parents’ job
text:
The police, with some reason, have often criticised the media for sensationalising the risks of a particular crime. But the modern media-savvy cop is also pretty good at pandering to that tendency. Simon Bailey, the chief constable of Norfolk, certainly is. In recent days, he has been all over the press, radio and television.

Raising the issue of sexual abuse of children by other children in the educational sector, Bailey has said, variously, that it’s “the next big national child sexual abuse scandal”, that the numbers on a website detailing examples of such abuse “are growing exponentially”, that this is “the tip of the iceberg” and that “this could be the biggest explosion of child sexual abuse since Jimmy Savile”. title: Pakistan PM Imran Khan prompts outrage with rape comments
text:
Imran Khan has grown increasingly conservative since returning to his home country from Britain and entering politics

In his playboy days as a handsome cricket star in 1980s London, Imran Khan was renowned for chasing models and actresses around the nightclub circuit. Decades on, the 65-year-old prime minister of Pakistan has provoked outrage with comments blaming women’s dress for a surge in rape cases in his home country.

During a televised interview, the Oxford-educated Khan fielded a question from a caller asking what his government was doing to combat a rise in sexual violence in Pakistan. Lashing out at declining standards of modesty among women, the prime minister replied that an increase in rape indicated the “consequences in any society where vulgarity is on the rise”.

text:
