We tried to give him a comfortable life — a wendy house with a heat lamp and a bed of straw, a garden in which to roam and two hens for company. But he was as disdainful of the Yorkshire weather as the next giant African tortoise, and made this clear by staying inside for days on end.

Irish supermarket chains have no immediate plans to follow Lidl in providing free sanitary products to women and girls, it has emerged.

title: Trials without juries will ease backlog, Sir Richard Henriques, QC, argues
text:
Lord Burnett of Maldon, the lord chief justice, said that reducing the number of jurors in individual cases from 12 to 7 was a possibility

Judges should sit without juries for criminal trials during lockdown, a top lawyer has argued.

Writing in The Times today, Sir Richard Henriques, QC, who last year published a report into the Metropolitan Police’s investigation of child sex abuse claims against senior figures, has backed a radical move that has not been seen since the height of the Troubles.

Sponsored

The justice secretary, Robert Buckland, QC, indicated yesterday that jury trials could be restarted later this month, as concern mounts over the backlog of crown court cases.

Jury trials were halted in March as part of measures to curb the spread of the virus. Sir Richard writes: “There is a simple and economical solution which would permit our crown courts to get back to work

Christian Brückner is suspected of kidnapping Madeleine in May 2007

text:
Julia James often walked her dog in the woods where her body was found

A police community support officer found murdered near woodland in Kent may have been the victim of a random attacker, detectives believe.

They are investigating whether Julia James, 53, who had worked for the police for nearly 15 years and had been commended for bravery, was set upon by a stranger.

She was found on a path at the edge of a field in Akholt Wood, Snowdown, near Dover, about 4pm on Tuesday. Her Jack Russell terrier was beside her body.

Officers from Kent’s serious crime directorate are investigating the attack on James, who is thought to have worked in the domestic violence unit. Officers are examining whether the attacker was in the area the previous day.

text:
The widespread abuse described on the website Everyone’s Invited undoubtedly signifies a failure or inability of schools and government to educate pupils and students in the definition and potential effects of such incidents.

The collective experiences posted on the website include the commission of criminal offences — many of them of a sexual nature.

title: Child abuse claims against Greek theatre director shine light on migrant plight
text:
Dimitris Lignadis, the former director of Greece’s national theatre, is accused of two rapes, one of a 14-year-old boy

In the seedy centre of Athens, a short stocky man approached a towering drag queen. He leans in to her, whispers something, and then, visibly irate, the transvestite points to the end of the street. The man, wearing grey trousers and a matching hat, moves down Omonia Square, and then stops before a yellow phone booth, spotting Mussa, a 17-year-old refugee boy.

He whispers something and they move off together. “It’s just sex,” Mussa tells me later. He has been stuck in Greece for four years, unable to reunite with family and friends in France, since fleeing his homeland, Algeria. “I have to survive.”

text:
Yesterday’s damning review into Scouting Ireland, and the organisation’s subsequent apology, will hopefully be some relief to the hundreds of victims of child sexual abuse.

Not only did it confirm a legacy of abuse and cover-up spanning decades, it also found that victims had previously tried to come forward but had been ignored or not believed.

title: Andrew Peacock obituary
text:
If any politician looked certain to become prime minister of Australia it was Andrew Peacock. At the age of 27 he was gifted Kooyong, the former seat of Sir Robert Menzies, Australia’s longest serving PM. He became foreign minister in his thirties, then leader of the Liberal Party not once, but twice. Yet both times the party was in opposition and the top job remained just beyond his reach.

Given Peacock’s seemingly effortless rise, good looks and glamour, not to mention a well-publicised affair with the Hollywood star Shirley MacLaine, he was the brunt of many a barbed comment from his Labor Party opponents. title: Up close and personal with Prince William: an intimate portrait of the future king
text:
Next month Prince William will celebrate his tenth wedding anniversary — the day he became a duke and embarked on the most formative decade of his life. Back then, the tentative 28-year-old newlywed was not ready to devote himself entirely to royal duties. A decade on, he is in a very different position.

The job of being the heir to the heir to the throne, of finding a balance between life and duty, is difficult at the best of times. These are not the best of times. In their bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey this month the Duke and Duchess of Sussex accused the royal family and the institution around it of racism and callous disregard for a suicidal newcomer, among many other damning charges.
summary:
Next month Prince William will celebrate his tenth wedding anniversary — the day he became a duke and embarked on the most formative decade of his life.
Back then, the tentative 28-year-old newlywed was not ready to devote himself entirely to royal duties.
A decade on, he is in a very different position.
The job of being the heir to the heir to the throne, of finding a balance between life and duty, is difficult at the best of times.
These are not the best of times.

Scotland Yard has been exonerated over its policing of the Sarah Everard vigil by an independent report that rounded on public figures who criticised the force.

Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire and Rescue Services found that police “did their best” to peacefully disperse the crowd at Clapham Common in south London, remained professional when subjected to abuse and were not heavy-handed.

title: SNP refuses to release key papers in Alex Salmond inquiry
text:
An inquiry is looking at the government’s investigation into allegations of inappropriate behaviour against Alex Salmond

SNP ministers are engulfed in another secrecy row after refusing to hand over key documents to an inquiry into the unlawful handling of complaints against Alex Salmond.

It was revealed yesterday that an unnamed individual has objected to information being released because their personal data is included in evidence.

This means that a tranche of information that was supposed to be passed to the inquiry will now be delayed.

The Holyrood inquiry is looking into the government’s investigation into allegations of inappropriate behaviour against Mr Salmond, 65, which the Court of Session ruled

title: Turks are turning back the clock on women’s rights
text:
I am absolutely fuming. Having spent the past two weeks in a bubble of rage and disbelief following Sarah Everard’s death and the subsequent conversation about women’s safety in Britain, I’ve been tipped over the edge by the Fatherland. Two days ago, Turkey left the Istanbul Convention.

Signed in 2011, the Istanbul Convention is a human rights treaty between 45 countries and the EU that aims to prevent violence against women (including domestic violence), protect victims and ensure perpetrators are duly punished. Turkey was the first to ratify it and I was so proud; it proved that the country wasn’t backward and the treaty’s title meant Turkey would forever be equated with a major advancement in women’s rights. Now all of this has been undone.
summary:
Having spent the past two weeks in a bubble of rage and disbelief following Sarah Everard’s death and the subsequent conversation about women’s safety in Britain, I’ve been tipped over the edge by the Fatherland.
Two days ago, Turkey left the Istanbul Convention.
Signed in 2011, the Istanbul Convention is a human rights treaty between 45 countries and the EU that aims to prevent violence against women (including domestic violence), protect victims and ensure perpetrators are duly punished.
Turkey was the first to ratify it and I was so proud; it proved that the country wasn’t backward and the treaty’s title meant Turkey would forever be equated with a major advancement in women’s rights.
Now all of this has been undone.

title: Newham murder accused ‘kept woman’s body in freezer for three years’
text:
Mihrican Mustafa was allegedly murdered, along with Henriett Szucs, by Zahid Younis

One of two vulnerable women whose battered bodies were found stuffed in a freezer is believed to have been there for three years, a court heard yesterday.

Henriett Szucs disappeared after moving in with her alleged killer at the house in Newham, east London, where her body was found.

Sponsored

Zahid Younis, 36, is accused of murdering her in August 2016 before killing Mihrican Mustafa in May 2018.

Both women, who struggled with drug addiction and spells of homelessness, would have been in their thirties.

Police officers searching for the defendant discovered the corpses in the small, locked chest freezer at his house last April, Southwark crown court was told this afternoon. He denies two charges of murder.

Duncan Penny, QC, for the prosecution, described Mr

Mihrican Mustafa was allegedly murdered, along with Henriett Szucs, by Zahid YounisOne of two vulnerable women whose battered bodies were found stuffed in a freezer is believed to have been there for three years, a court heard yesterday.
Henriett Szucs disappeared after moving in with her alleged killer at the house in Newham, east London, where her body was found.

title: Balmoral guard John Paul Hoy guilty of raping girls
text:
John Hoy. One of his victims said: ’I was a little girl. I was living in terror some days’

A former soldier who was part of the Queen’s guard at Balmoral has been found guilty of carrying out a campaign of child abuse which he began at the age of 12.

John Paul Hoy repeatedly raped two girls and indecently assaulted a third in his home city of Edinburgh between 1986 and 1996.

Sponsored

Hoy, now 46, was aged 12 when he began committing sex offences against younger children. He molested victims and raped two of the girls at houses in the city.

Hoy, of Edinburgh, had denied all the charges but was found guilty yesterday of 11 offences: four of rape, two of indecent assault and five of indecent conduct. He was acquitted of a further rape charge against a girl aged 14 or

title: £4m paid to victims of child abuse
text:
The early payout scheme is aimed at victims of child abuse who are now over 68 or have a terminal illness

More than 400 victims of historic child abuse in care have shared about £4 million in payouts from the Scottish government.

In April 2019, the Advance Payment Scheme was launched, promising £10,000 to those who were abused in care before 2004 and aged over 68 years old or with a terminal illness.

Sponsored

The initiative was put in place ahead of a statutory redress scheme, which is expected to pass the Scottish parliament in March 2021. The advance scheme was set up to ensure that older sufferers of abuse will be able to access the payments while younger victims will be able to access the financial redress in the wider scheme.

John Swinney, the deputy first minister, said: “While clearly nothing can take away the pain

title: Justin Baldoni is on a crusade against toxic masculinity – starting with his own
text:
Most of my life I have been told men are in crisis. Perhaps we finally are. The hashtags that have of late been in our pursuit – #MeToo, #TimesUp, #EverydaySexism – send us in the dead of night word-searching the transcripts of our lives for transgressions. We may beerily protest that woke has gone too far, but how carefully we now phrase our opinions of women. We know the truth. Out in the world, women’s physical violation by our gender is running wild. Yet, and just as doggedly, the 21st century targets the male with advertisements for a robust masculine ideal that would have us preen our bodies, chase material success, strive for the qualities of “leadership” (aka dominance) and unwind to bespoke pornography.

Should
summary:
Most of my life I have been told men are in crisis.
The hashtags that have of late been in our pursuit – #MeToo, #TimesUp, #EverydaySexism – send us in the dead of night word-searching the transcripts of our lives for transgressions.
We may beerily protest that woke has gone too far, but how carefully we now phrase our opinions of women.
We know the truth.
Out in the world, women’s physical violation by our gender is running wild.

title: The Crown’s Erin Doherty: how I became a Princess Anne superfan
text:
As it manoeuvres into the bloody battlefields of the Eighties, the fourth season of Netflix’s The Crown brings out the big guns: Thatcher and Diana. Yet this autumn’s episodes boast no more affecting or powerful scene than a quiet encounter between the Queen and her daughter, Princess Anne, in the grounds of Gatcombe Park, Anne’s Gloucestershire home. It hits the viewer resoundingly, like a nail on the head, or a bullet to it.

It is 1981. Anne is unhappy. The press, head over heels with Diana, is out to get the older woman. Having relished scaring people, she is now scared herself, alone and friendless. Her eight-year marriage to Mark Phillips persists only in name. The Queen has heard from the head of royal protection
summary:
As it manoeuvres into the bloody battlefields of the Eighties, the fourth season of Netflix’s The Crown brings out the big guns: Thatcher and Diana.
Yet this autumn’s episodes boast no more affecting or powerful scene than a quiet encounter between the Queen and her daughter, Princess Anne, in the grounds of Gatcombe Park, Anne’s Gloucestershire home.
It hits the viewer resoundingly, like a nail on the head, or a bullet to it.
Anne is unhappy.
The press, head over heels with Diana, is out to get the older woman.

title: Facebook encryption leaves children vulnerable to predators
text:
Last week a man was jailed for 25 years for 96 child sex offences. The National Crime Agency labelled David Wilson one of Britain’s most prolific abusers and suggested he may have contacted 5,000 boys online.

While social media was key to his offending it was also key to his conviction. Facebook provided 20 reports of boys aged 12 to 15 sending self-generated images to what they thought was a 13-year-old girl. This account actually belonged to a 36-year-old man posing as a girl to groom his victims.

title: Private detective joins search for Briton Sarm Heslop
text:
A private investigator has been called in to hunt for clues to the whereabouts of a British tourist missing in the US Virgin Islands.

Friends or family of Sarm Heslop’s American boyfriend, Ryan Bane, have hired the detective as frustration mounts over the handling of the case by US Virgin Islands police, who have asked the FBI to “support” but not lead the inquiry.

Sponsored

“I am confidently saying I know Ryan is innocent but we need to get real authorities involved,” Flora Pickard, a friend of Bane, said yesterday. Bane, 44, called police early on March 8 to report Heslop, 41, missing from his luxury catamaran, Siren Song, on which they had lived together for several months. It was moored around 150ft from shore
summary:

title: Murder and rape suspects charged by post
text:
Dame Vera Baird said that the trend was concerning for victims and society

People suspected of crimes including murder and rape are increasingly being charged by post, figures suggest.

Last year Britain’s biggest police force sent 12 suspects letters telling them they would be tried for murder, an increase of seven compared with the previous year. In 2017 two were sent. The Metropolitan Police also issued postal charges to 91 people suspected of rape in 2019 — more than double the previous year’s figure of 43. Letters were also sent to 414 people charging them with sex offences.

Sponsored

Dame Vera Baird, QC, the victims’ commissioner for England and Wales, said the figures were “deeply concerning for victims and for society”. A senior solicitor said charging a suspect with murder by post simply gave them time to go on
summary:
Dame Vera Baird said that the trend was concerning for victims and societyPeople suspected of crimes including murder and rape are increasingly being charged by post, figures suggest.
Last year Britain’s biggest police force sent 12 suspects letters telling them they would be tried for murder, an increase of seven compared with the previous year.

title: Your Honor review — the whiter than white judge who breaks bad
text:
Your Honor

Sky Atlantic

★★★★☆

Why is Covid Killing People of Colour?

BBC1

★★★☆☆

Sponsored

Bryan Cranston is one of those actors who’s so good he’d be watchable in an advert for haemorrhoid cream. That’s a fact. Google his early role in a 1980s commercial for proof. Yet, however convincing he is as a man with rectal issues, he’s at his best when playing a good man forced into desperate behaviour — when his upstanding morality is nuked by circumstance and his face contorts into a grimace of stress as he breaks bad.

title: Keeley Hawes on life with Matthew Macfadyen, acting in a pandemic and loneliness
text:
Sadly this bleak midwinter it does not fall to Keeley Hawes to take our minds off the Grim Reaper — but then how was British television’s favourite actress to know that a pandemic would bring universal resonance to the three separate dramas she was about to star in? Although Finding Alice, It’s a Sin and To Olivia are hugely different in tone from one another, they are all much possessed by death. Each time, however, Hawes attacks this meatiest of subjects with something like relish. At one point, as we discuss the most distressing of the productions, Russell T Davies’s Eighties Aids serial, she describes working on It’s a Sin as “an absolute joy”. Watch and you will understand what she means.

Death is
summary:
Sadly this bleak midwinter it does not fall to Keeley Hawes to take our minds off the Grim Reaper — but then how was British television’s favourite actress to know that a pandemic would bring universal resonance to the three separate dramas she was about to star in?
Although Finding Alice, It’s a Sin and To Olivia are hugely different in tone from one another, they are all much possessed by death.
Each time, however, Hawes attacks this meatiest of subjects with something like relish.

Watch and you will understand what she means.

title: German AI posts fake child-abuse videos online to catch abusers
text:
The images have been used to gain access to digital child abuse networks

Police have used a computer to generate fake videos of child abuse to help them to infiltrate an online paedophile ring.

The controversial technique, which was legalised by the Bundestag in January, allows artificial intelligence (AI) software to “watch” a database of tens of thousands of impounded clips of sexual violence against children. Over time the AI learns to produce its own video, which undercover investigators can use to win the confidence of paedophiles on secretive internet forums.

Sponsored

Ministers argue that this is often the only way to break open digital child abuse networks, which frequently refuse to admit new members unless they upload their own material. The artificial images can be deployed as a last resort when there is no realistic alternative for

Recall Harry Corsham and thief-taker Peregrine Child from Laura Shepherd-Robinson’s excellent Blood & Sugar? Now it is Harry’s wife, Lady Caroline Corsham who employs Child in her quest for justice for a woman she had good reason to like and trust.

title: Freedom(ish)! What’s the first thing you did post-lockdown?
text:
Hannah Betts: ”One doesn’t even need to pack, should one be prepared to go knickerless the next day, which I very much am”

I’m booking a mini-break. Hotel sex is a different kind of sex. Elegant. Athletic. Showier

Hannah Betts

Lockdown 2 — it’s over, bitches, and I for one will be running about yelling, “Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!” like one of the yob oiks at the beginning of Julius Caesar. title: I served 17 years in jail but DNA proves real rapist is still at large
text:
Andrew Malkinson was convicted of rape despite no forensic evidence against him

A man who spent 17 years in prison for rape and maintained his innocence is a step closer to clearing his name after a fresh DNA breakthrough in his case.

Andrew Malkinson was convicted of raping a 33-year-old mother left for dead on a Manchester roadside in the middle of the night in July 2003.

Sponsored

There was never any forensic evidence against him and his conviction depended on an identity parade and testimony from witnesses whose criminal pasts were hidden from the court.

Andrew Malkinson’s ex-girlfriend, Karin Schuitemaker, never doubted his innocence

Malkinson, 55, who was 37 when he went to jail, was released from prison last December for good behaviour. He was locked up for ten years beyond his tariff because he refused to admit to the crime.

title: Edgard Tupët-Thomé obituary
text:
On August 27, 1944, Lieutenant Edgard Tupët-Thomé and his small team of men flew in an RAF Stirling towards the Jura mountains on the Swiss border. They were members of the British-trained “French SAS” and they were on a mission to assist embattled maquisards of the French Resistance. Although injured during his parachute jump, Tupët-Thomé joined his men in attacking the heavily defended village of Clerval. They killed 30 Germans and destroyed a Panzer tank.

The following month he was assigned to assist the US 7th Army as a reconnaissance officer in the Alsace-Lorraine region on the French- German border where, on September 23, he dragged a wounded American soldier to safety under heavy enemy mortar fire and killed “several scores of Germans”, according to
summary:

title: Mastercard “allegedly linked to phantom transactions”
text:
The allegations are in a report for a bank that had links with Wirecard

A Mastercard executive allegedly was involved in a money-laundering operation at a bank accused of terrorist financing and organised crime that had links to Wirecard, the disgraced German payments group.

A report commissioned by the owners of FBME Bank in Cyprus uncovered evidence of apparent criminal activity, including an alleged operation designed to trick the international card payments system into processing high-risk and potentially illegal transactions.

Sponsored

Private investigators found the “apparent involvement of a senior Mastercard employee in criminal activities” and recommended that the bank’s shareholders tell prosecutors in the United States that a source of the problem “may be with Mastercard”.

The investigation, called Project Waxwing, was commissioned after the US Treasury’s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network froze FBME out of the American banking

title: Dulwich College turns boys into sexual abusers, former pupil claims
text:
Billie Errington says Dulwich boys ‘trolled’ a Facebook page she set up when at school

Dulwich College is today accused of being a “breeding ground for sexual predators” in an open letter organised by a former schoolboy that contains more than 100 anonymous accounts of assault, harassment and sharing intimate photos online.

The letter, written by Samuel Schulenburg, 19, a former pupil at the south London private school, said “experiences of assault, revenge pornography and slut shaming were exacerbated by ... young men who ... laughed at stories of sexual violence”.

Sponsored

His letter includes about 100 anonymous testimonies written by girls who went to neighbouring schools, such as James Allen’s Girls’ School (Jags). One claims there was “an established rape culture” at the school.

In a statement issued yesterday, Dr Joe Spence, master at Dulwich, said the school “condemned unreservedly”
summary:

text:
Paul Parks, who served in the SAS, was banned from the clergy for two years

A former soldier who became a vicar has been defrocked for abusing his wife, whom he called “Jezebel”, for 14 years.

The Rev Paul Parks, 60, formerly rector of St Helen’s Ore and St Barnabas in Hastings, was arrested in 2017 after his wife revealed the abuse, which included beating her and threatening to stab her with a letter opener.

title: US seeks allies for boycott of Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022
text:
Players from Tsinghua University and Renmin University of China play in a test event for the 2022 Winter Olympics

The United States is considering boycotting the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, a state department spokesman said yesterday amid mounting international criticism of China’s human rights abuses.

Ned Price said that the US was consulting with like-minded countries to determine how to proceed. It is understood that the British government has not been approached with any boycott proposal, although ministers have not ruled out the option.

Sponsored

Asked whether the Biden administration was considering a boycott with allies, Price said: “Part of our review of those Olympics and our thinking will involve close consultations with partners and allies around the world.

“We have consistently said when it comes to our concerns with the government in Beijing, including Beijing’s egregious human rights violations, its conduct of genocide

title: Times letters: Planning shake-up and the housing crisis
text:
Sir, The government’s planning reforms, which will water down requirements for affordable homes and do away with agreements that benefit local communities, represent a lost opportunity for social mobility (“Homes target places Johnson on collision course with Tory shires”, Aug 7). Research on successive generations in Britain reveals a growing home ownership divide opening up once again: today’s adults are now far less likely to own a home if their parents were not themselves homeowners. This is part of a wider wealth divide in society and mirrors the decline observed in social mobility levels.

If we are to have any chance of improving social mobility for future generations we need both greater opportunities overall but also targeted help for the less fortunate. That is as
summary:
Sir, The government’s planning reforms, which will water down requirements for affordable homes and do away with agreements that benefit local communities, represent a lost opportunity for social mobility (“Homes target places Johnson on collision course with Tory shires”, Aug 7).
Research on successive generations in Britain reveals a growing home ownership divide opening up once again: today’s adults are now far less likely to own a home if their parents were not themselves homeowners.
This is part of a wider wealth divide in society and mirrors the decline observed in social mobility levels.
If we are to have any chance of improving social mobility for future generations we need both greater opportunities overall but also targeted help for the less fortunate.

title: The Tommy Tiernan Show deserves to be talked up
text:
As with everything else, the pandemic has created problems for television. The filming of drama series was postponed, and chat shows suffered from a lack of in-studio audiences and guests. But a year on, TV production has found a rhythm and, with other avenues of entertainment shut off and everyone at home, it’s the ideal time to be making brilliant television.

The Tommy Tiernan Show, in which the comedian has no idea whom he’s interviewing until they sit opposite him, has been a cut above since it started as a radio experiment in 2015. title: Highs and lows of reporters on screen
text:
The “bad journalist” is a stock character in Hollywood movies. Deceitful, corrupt and immoral, they make up quotes, take bribes, or use blackmail and threats to get stories. Think of the character Walter Burns in The Front Page, Kirk Douglas’s amoral hack in Billy Wilder’s Ace in the Hole, or the reporter played by Sally Field in Absence of Malice.

Yet none of these, I would argue, is as “bad” as the journalist in Godless, a western drama mini-series made for Netflix. AT Grigg, the editor of the Santa Fe Daily Review, as portrayed by actor Jeremy Bobb, may just be the most evil journalist yet seen on screen.

Sponsored

Grigg knows that the demonic Frank Griffin (brilliantly played by Jeff Daniels)
summary:
The “bad journalist” is a stock character in Hollywood movies.
Deceitful, corrupt and immoral, they make up quotes, take bribes, or use blackmail and threats to get stories.
Think of the character Walter Burns in The Front Page, Kirk Douglas’s amoral hack in Billy Wilder’s Ace in the Hole, or the reporter played by Sally Field in Absence of Malice.
Yet none of these, I would argue, is as “bad” as the journalist in Godless, a western drama mini-series made for Netflix.
AT Grigg, the editor of the Santa Fe Daily Review, as portrayed by actor Jeremy Bobb, may just be the most evil journalist yet seen on screen.

title: Soft Power by Robert Winder review — Max Hastings on a new method of global dominance
text:
Influential: Coca-Cola is recognisable in any language around the world

I once spent a grim morning in Gaza, hearing a procession of Palestinians denounce the iniquity of the United States for indulging Israel’s occupation policies. Inside those hate-filled people’s houses, however, I glimpsed their children sitting before televisions, gripped by Hollywood movies.

Likewise, the Americans suffered humiliating military defeat in Vietnam, but today’s Vietnamese embrace US culture, commerce and values with an enthusiasm that persuades me that, where B-52s and Spooky gunships failed, Scarlett Johansson and McDonald’s have proved invincible.

Sponsored

These are manifestations of soft power, the theme of this book by Robert Winder, the former literary editor of The Independent and author of books about immigration and Englishness. A nation’s standing in the world, he writes, has in recent times not been measured only

title: Parking tickets more costly than wives in Utah
text:
Utah has recategorised bigamy as an infraction, punishable by community service or a maximum fine of $750

Bigamy is no longer a serious crime in Utah and now counts as an offence on a par with a parking ticket.

A state law came into effect this week that recategorised the practice as an infraction, punishable by community service or a maximum fine of $750, after decades during which it was classed as a felony and offenders could face five years in prison and a $5,000 fine.

Sponsored

The shift in the state’s approach was opposed by groups who argued that polygamy is abusive to women and children, but it passed the state legislature in February with massive support and was signed into law by Gary Herbert, the state governor, in March.

title: ‘Bullying’ physio is jailed for 9 years for rape and assaults
text:
Derek Adams was also found guilty of physically assaulting four women and two children at the High Court in Edinburgh

A physiotherapist who committed a series of sex attacks on four women during a catalogue of violence has been jailed for nine years.

Derek Adams carried out the assaults against adult women and children over more than 20 years.

Sponsored

Adams, 59, had denied a string of charges during a trial at the High Court in Edinburgh, but was convicted of 12 offences, including two rapes, an attempted rape and an indecent assault.

He was also found guilty of physically assaulting four women and two children, including a two-year-old girl.

title: The New Mutants review — their superpower is the ability to make you yawn
text:
★★☆☆☆

In this listless franchise reboot, a fresh batch of would-be X-Men are imprisoned in an institution by a sinister woman while they learn to control their demons. You could call it One Flew Over the Mutant’s Nest if it had an ounce of wit or personality. What we actually get is a combination of splashy horror and turgid teenage soap as our angsty charges, supervised with ferocious blankness by Dr Reyes (Alice Braga from City of God, failing to channel Nurse Ratched), shuffle through their superhero puberty.

Directed by Josh Boone, who made the adolescent cancer flick The Fault in Our Stars, the film uses mutants to explore an exhausting list of social issues: depression, inclusivity, homosexuality, self-harm, child abuse, racism and
summary:

title: Prince Philip obituary
text:
‘He looked,” recalled his aide and friend Michael Parker, “as if you’d dropped half the world on him.” Prince Philip and the young Princess Elizabeth had travelled to Kenya at the beginning of 1952 at the start of a royal tour, standing in for King George VI, who was too ill to travel. News reached them of the King’s sudden death, aged 56. The duke’s wife was 25 and he was 30. Born to privilege but not to duty, he would now and for the years to follow embrace duty. His life had changed key. Until its end he would be a tireless consort to the Queen. It was a responsibility that he had not expected so young, yet which thereafter he shouldered with energy,

Sponsored

title: Madeleine McCann police send divers down 50ft wells
text:
British police still regard Madeleine McCann as missing; German prosecutors say they have evidence she is dead

Police searching for Madeleine McCann have used divers to examine wells on land close to where the German paedophile suspected of her abduction had stayed.

The land is off a road leading to the Boca do Rio and Barranco beaches on the Algarve coast where Christian Brückner often parked his motorhome at the time of Madeleine’s disappearance 13 years ago.

Sponsored

The land contains more than 20 wells. Police and firefighters searched the site on Thursday with divers focusing on three 50ft (15m) wells full of rubbish and vegetation.

Information from the German police and Scotland Yard’s Operation Grange investigation into Madeleine’s disappearance had prompted the search, Correio da Manha reported.

title: Penne for your thoughts
text:
The chances of an Italian holiday this summer look slimmer than the thinnest slice of prosciutto, but we can all learn to conjure up a taste of Italy at home. The country has some of the most envy-inducing food in the world, but even the experts insist that cooking like an Italian is not that complicated — though a good delicatessen helps. “Eating like an Italian is more a state of mind than only using Italian ingredients,” says Manuela Spinelli, the secretary-general of Euro-Toques Ireland, the Irish branch of the European community of chefs and cooks.

In non-foodie circles, Spinelli is probably better known in her other role as a translator, most famously for Giovanni Trapattoni while he was managing the Republic of Ireland football
summary:

title: Caitlin Moran: me and my revolting daughters
text:
I remember my father’s confusion when, in the mid-Nineties, the incoming tide of Britpop resurrected all the things from his teenage years. After decades of punk, synthesizers and acid house, suddenly his teenage daughter and her mates were all into the Beatles and the Beach Boys, Mod parkas, Minis, and minis, and The Italian Job.

“Why are you digging up all of our old stuff?” he would half-complain, half-jeer, as Carnaby Street started to “swing” again, and men I knew scoured vintage shops to, very possibly, buy the old trousers he’d given away in 1969. “The point was that, when we were doing it, it was new: we were rebelling against our parents. You guys can’t rebel by doing something old. You
summary:
I remember my father’s confusion when, in the mid-Nineties, the incoming tide of Britpop resurrected all the things from his teenage years.
After decades of punk, synthesizers and acid house, suddenly his teenage daughter and her mates were all into the Beatles and the Beach Boys, Mod parkas, Minis, and minis, and The Italian Job.
“Why are you digging up all of our old stuff?” he would half-complain, half-jeer, as Carnaby Street started to “swing” again, and men I knew scoured vintage shops to, very possibly, buy the old trousers he’d given away in 1969.
“The point was that, when we were doing it, it was new: we were rebelling against our parents.
You guys can’t rebel by doing something old.

title: Warrant was served to obtain government’s Salmond papers
text:
Some documents were ruled inadmissible at Alex Salmond’s trial, at which he was cleared of all charges

Prosecutors resorted to serving a warrant on the Scottish government to obtain documents linked to the investigation into sexual assault allegations against Alex Salmond, it has emerged.

The Crown Office issued the warrant last autumn as it built its case against the former first minister and exchanged correspondence with officials over the requested disclosure. A spokesman for the Scottish government insisted that they had asked for the warrant to be issued to ensure “legal certainty” in providing the documents.

Sponsored

The documents were disclosed before court hearings against Mr Salmond but a number of them were ruled inadmissible in his trial at the High Court in Edinburgh. In March, Mr Salmond was cleared of all charges.

title: Clive Myrie survived war zones, came home to be a BBC anchorman — and got racist abuse and death threats
text:
‘Articulate” does not begin to describe Clive Myrie of BBC News. He is the best writer in its reporters’ room — I cite in evidence the moment when, over footage of a ramshackle tent village in Sudan, he asked viewers to “imagine what those displaced are running from if this is what they are running to”. He possesses its finest speaking voice: a deep, warm baritone. Out of his special assignments he makes sophisticated mini documentaries where others merely go on a bit longer than usual. In the presenter’s chair, when Huw Edwards is not around, he exudes attention and authority, and must surely be the frontrunner eventually to succeed him.

title: Church stance on extramarital sex left Maids Moreton elderly victims vulnerable, review finds
text:
The Church of England’s position that sex should only be between a married man and woman left two elderly neighbours vulnerable to seduction by a manipulative churchwarden, an official review said today.

Benjamin Field, 29, emotionally abused Peter Farquhar, 69, before seducing his neighbour, Ann Moore-Martin, 83, in the village of Maids Moreton, Buckinghamshire. Field was convicted of the murder of Mr Farquhar in October last year.

Sponsored

An independent review commissioned by the Diocese of Oxford recommends greater awareness of social isolation and “need for intimacy” of older people and to challenge ageism and attitudes towards homosexuality within the church.

It found that Field had “groomed” the vicar and the entire congregation at Stowe parish church.

title: Helpline for pupils as ministers launch school sex abuse inquiry
text:
Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said that victims would also now receive better support if they wanted to refer abuse allegations to the police

Sexual abuse in schools is to be investigated by the education inspectorate after pressure from senior politicians and experts.

The charity NSPCC will set up a helpline to provide support to victims and Ofsted has been asked to review school safeguarding policies immediately, ministers announced yesterday.

Soma Sara, who founded the website, welcomed the review, but said she was disappointed that Everyone’s Invited had not been involved or consulted about the action.

title: Woman raped by priest set to sue over Catholic Church’s response
text:
A woman sexually abused by a priest has threatened legal action against the Catholic church after officials branded her “needy” and “manipulative”.

The abuse, and later rape, began when she was 15 and continued for years. She reported her allegations to the church in 2016 and received a settlement in 2018.

Sponsored

It is understood that the woman has sent a letter threatening legal action on the grounds of personal injury after alleging she was “re-traumatised” at the hands of safeguarding staff when she disclosed the abuse.

The case is against the Archdiocese of Westminster, of which Cardinal Vincent Nichols, leader of the Catholic church in England and Wales, is head. It is understood that Nichols is named repeatedly in the letter. No personal legal liability

title: Scourge of the investment scammers
text:
Investment scams have nearly quadrupled during lockdown as scammers use ever more sophisticated methods to dupe ordinary savers into parting with their cash.

Almost £10 million was lost to the frauds last month, up from about £4million in July, according to the Investment Association. The total number of reported scans has jumped from 300 to 1,175 over the same period, affecting about 200 people, the group said.

Sponsored

Scammers are taking advantage of more people working from home where online security may be less robust than in their workplace. With Christmas shopping well under way and lockdown forcing more of us to buy online, there is a rich seam for criminals to exploit.

Criminals are cloning genuine investment management companies, using their logos and website designs
summary:
Investment scams have nearly quadrupled during lockdown as scammers use ever more sophisticated methods to dupe ordinary savers into parting with their cash.

title: Abingdon School pupil expelled for online rape threats
text:
The 15-year-old’s parents have argued that Abingdon School had no right to invade a child’s life on social media

A teenager who was expelled from a top private school for sending antisemitic images and rape threats online had his privacy invaded, his parents have claimed as they vowed to fight his expulsion.

The 15-year-old at Abingdon School in Oxfordshire sent a series of “highly offensive” jokes including a picture of three people dressed as Nazi soldiers with the caption “Happy Birthday”, a disciplinary hearing was told.

Sponsored

He was said to have sent the image to another Abingdon student, who comes from a Jewish family, over Snapchat.

In another incident the schoolboy allegedly made a rape threat in a video on TikTok. A female user on the app posted a clip of herself removing a balaclava with the caption “what would you do if I

title: Prince Harry: the Firm cut me off financially
text:
Prince Harry suggested that his mother left him a fortune because she foresaw that he would be cut off financially.

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex claim that they were forced to move to the Los Angeles home of the billionaire film producer Tyler Perry, 51, because the Prince of Wales ended their funding and their security was withdrawn.

Sponsored

Much of the bitterness towards the royal family appears to be as a result of Prince Charles’s decision to withdraw the couple’s private allowance when they stepped down as working royals. Harry, 36, told Oprah Winfrey: “My family literally cut me off financially. I’ve got what my mum left me and without that, we would not have been able to do this. I think she saw

text:
For full TV listings for the week, see thetimes.co.uk/tvplanner

Sky Documentaries, 9pm

title: Lewis Morgan praying Inter Miami remains on Steve Clarke’s mind
text:
There’s a lot of love for Lewis Morgan at Inter Miami. He wears the No 7 shirt synonymous with David Beckham, one of the club’s owners, was named its Most Valuable Player (MVP) in his debut season and recently agreed a new three-year contract with the praise of Phil Neville, his new manager, ringing in his ears.

A skilful, goalscoring winger, who made his name at St Mirren after being released by Rangers, then stalled slightly as a squad man at Celtic, the 24-year-old is back to doing what he does best: running at defenders and cutting inside from either flank to shoot. Morgan makes it crystal clear that he will do his utmost to make a late run into Steve Clarke’s Scotland squad for

title: Four held over rape of two 15-year-old British girls in southern Italy
text:
Several of the men arrested by Italian police were previously investigated for drug-dealing or violence

Italian police have arrested four men and are investigating four other suspects in connection with the alleged drugging and gang rape of two 15-year-old British girls on holiday in the south of the country.

The rape reportedly took place in the early hours of Tuesday morning at a house party in the small town of Marconia in Basilicata, the region in the arch of the heel of Italy.

Sponsored

“The four Italian suspects, all local men aged 19-23, were arrested at dawn on Friday after being identified by the complainants and CCTV,” said Luigi Vessio, the local flying squad chief.

CCTV footage released by police shows a group of men running at the rear of the villa

“We are investigating four other suspects who we believe were present and watched during the incident.”

The girls are thought to have attended a party the

title: Prolific paedophile Gordon Neely abused me at Rangers, says former player
text:
The anonymous player says he was abused in the manager’s dressing room at Ibrox

A former top-flight footballer has come forward to claim he was repeatedly abused in a manager’s office at Ibrox while he was a youth player with Rangers.

The retired professional alleges he was indecently assaulted by Gordon Neely, the club’s head of youth development, in the late 1980s.

Sponsored

Neely was unmasked as a prolific paedophile in the report into sexual abuse within football, which was commissioned by the Scottish FA and published last week.

It found he sexually and physically abused at least three other youths at Ibrox and previously molested other young players at Hibernian and Hutchison Vale, an Edinburgh youth side. title: Most big religions start off as cults — could QAnon ever go mainstream?
text:
I hesitate to write about QAnon. Why offer the oxygen of publicity to a bizarre online conspiracy theory that claims there is a vast paedophile network orchestrated by the political and business elites that will eventually be taken down by Donald Trump? Shouldn’t we ignore such delusions or, perhaps, even censor them?

I am not so sure. I think we have something to learn from QAnon — about ourselves and our relationship with truth. Moreover, I suspect the more that powerful institutions such as Twitter and the US government seek to suppress it, the faster it will grow, at least in the short term, spurred on by its underdog status, finding ever more purchase in the nooks and crannies of digital culture.

Sponsored

Perhaps the
summary:
I hesitate to write about QAnon.
Why offer the oxygen of publicity to a bizarre online conspiracy theory that claims there is a vast paedophile network orchestrated by the political and business elites that will eventually be taken down by Donald Trump?
Shouldn’t we ignore such delusions or, perhaps, even censor them?
I am not so sure.
I think we have something to learn from QAnon — about ourselves and our relationship with truth.

title: Boxer Callum Hancock: my fight to overcome childhood sexual abuse
text:
Callum Hancock is a boxer from Eckington, a small town just south of Sheffield on the Derbyshire-Yorkshire border. He is 29 years old, 6ft 3in tall and has a perfect record at professional level: ten fights, ten wins, one knockout. In person he is modest and gently spoken but knows there is no point in pretending that, under the right circumstances, he is anything other than dangerous. “I’m tall. I’ve got long, powerful shots. I’ve got a good straight jab. My work rate is relentless. My speed, my timing, my reflexes… Everything’s on point,” he says calmly, without bravado. “When I fight, I feel like I’m in tune.”

Violence has dominated Hancock’s life for a very long time. When he unpacks himself it is there,
summary:
Callum Hancock is a boxer from Eckington, a small town just south of Sheffield on the Derbyshire-Yorkshire border.
He is 29 years old, 6ft 3in tall and has a perfect record at professional level: ten fights, ten wins, one knockout.
I’ve got long, powerful shots.
My speed, my timing, my reflexes… Everything’s on point,” he says calmly, without bravado.
“When I fight, I feel like I’m in tune.”Violence has dominated Hancock’s life for a very long time.

title: Victoria Derbyshire’s sons back her in abuse campaign
text:
The teenage sons of the BBC presenter Victoria Derbyshire have used her Twitter feed to urge victims of domestic abuse to seek help, after their mother suffered years of violence from her father.

Ollie, 16, and Joe, 13, are in charge of their mother’s social media accounts while she is a contestant on the ITV reality programme I’m a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!, being held in the grounds of a castle in Wales.

Sponsored

As a child, Derbyshire said her whole body would tense when she heard her father’s key turn in the lock of their home. Sometimes he would whip her with a belt, on other occasions he would hit her around the head, she said.

title: The Assistant review — Weinstein’s office culture is exposed
text:
★★★★☆

Despite the best intentions in the world, depicting rape and abuse of women on screen is never neutral, always compromised. Male film-makers have been at it for years and have argued about the need for these scenes as narrative motivation (the slow reveal of the rape in The Accused), or as part of an exploration of male violence (the horrific abuse of Jessica Alba’s character in The Killer Inside Me), or as the defining moment in a female protagonist’s psyche (the rape of Lisbeth Salander in The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, both versions).

But, try as they might, it’s almost impossible to eradicate entirely the whiff of prurience that mixes freely with shock and outrage. The scenes become a deliberate

text:

title: Cronyism in Scouting Ireland ‘protected child abusers for decades’
text:
A report found 275 known or suspected abusers who worked at Scouting Ireland’s predecessor organisations

Senior figures in Scouting Ireland helped to cover up cases of child sex abuse and some had a “sexual interest in young people”, a damning review of the organisation has found.

The body apologised yesterday, admitting that it had failed victims, many of whom had previously attempted to come forward.

Sponsored

“Individuals who had a sexual interest in young people rose to positions of power and influence on occasions and controlled any fledgling accountability processes, preventing known offenders from being removed from scouting,” the review found.

Ian Elliott, a child protection expert commissioned by Scouting Ireland to write the review, said that “cronyism thrived, and remained a significant problem” up to 2017.

title: Chinese police ‘routinely spy on British visitors’
text:
British visitors to China are being routinely spied on by the country’s police, according to a leaked database that has been handed to MI5.

A Chinese police security watchlist contains the names of 150 British citizens who have travelled to Shanghai for business or leisure.

Sponsored

The security database stored data on their dates of birth, passport numbers and their points of entry and exit.

Among them were British government officials, businessmen and even tourists, according to a leak of the watchlist obtained by a cyber-security consultancy, which passed its findings to The Daily Telegraph. They appear alongside other international visitors.

The database also has files on 7,600 Uighur Muslims in Shanghai who are blacklisted on the watchlist as “terrorists” and criminals for alleged offences
summary:
British visitors to China are being routinely spied on by the country’s police, according to a leaked database that has been handed to MI5.
A Chinese police security watchlist contains the names of 150 British citizens who have travelled to Shanghai for business or leisure.
SponsoredThe security database stored data on their dates of birth, passport numbers and their points of entry and exit.
Among them were British government officials, businessmen and even tourists, according to a leak of the watchlist obtained by a cyber-security consultancy, which passed its findings to The Daily Telegraph.
The database also has files on 7,600 Uighur Muslims in Shanghai who are blacklisted on the watchlist as “terrorists” and criminals for alleged offences

title: Australian war crimes report: Billionaire offers to pay legal fees for SAS accused
text:
Body camera footage from Australian SAS forces in Afghanistan has shocked both nations. In one video, a soldier whose identity has been hidden by the Australian authorities is seen shooting and killing an unarmed Afghan man who is clutching red prayer beads as he cowers in a field. He was one of dozens killed

An Australian media mogul has offered funding for troops who are potentially facing prosecution for unlawful killings in Afghanistan.

Kerry Stokes, 80, the majority owner of Australia’s most popular television network, has extended a $1.9 million (£1.04 million) loan to Ben Roberts-Smith, the country’s most decorated living soldier, who has been told that he is being treated as a suspect.

Sponsored

The loan was originally intended to fund Mr Roberts-Smith’s legal costs to sue two newspapers for defamation.

Kerry Stokes has offered to pay the soldier’s legal fees ROB D’RAINE/GETTY IMAGES

However, a spokesman for Mr Stokes said today that he was now also offering to fund the costs of other former and current SAS members who are set to be investigated for unlawful killings.

title: The rise and rise of the micro wedding
text:
Leanne Baily, 33, from Essex, has watched her friends struggle to raise up to £40,000 to spend on their big fat weddings — only in some cases, sadly, to get divorced soon afterwards. So when lockdown gave her the chance to enjoy a “micro wedding” to her fiancé, Alan Warren, 41, from Lancashire, she grabbed it. The couple had planned to have a ceremony with only six guests on New Year’s Eve last year. “We wanted to say goodbye to a rubbish year and start the new year on a high,” Baily recalls.

When second-wave restrictions nixed their plan, the couple rescheduled for next month at a venue with cottages near Truro, Cornwall, with the same six guests — even though they could have had

title: QC John Watt facing child sex abuse charges to be extradited
text:
The Police Scotland investigation started when Susie Henderson made allegations against some of the country’s leading lawyers

A Scottish lawyer is set to be extradited from America to face charges of child sexual abuse.

John Watt, QC, a former prosecutor, is accused of sexual assaults on four children in the 1970s and 1980s.

Sponsored

One of them is Susie Henderson, now 53, whose claims of a paedophile ring in the Scottish legal establishment led to a six-year police investigation. Among those she accused of sexual offences against children was Sir Nicholas Fairbairn, QC, the late Tory MP.

Mr Watt, 70, could be in Scotland by October after a US judge approved his removal despite his claims that his extradition should be stopped for “humanitarian” reasons due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Letters to the Editor: Roy Greenslade’s IRA hypocrisy is a stain on the press
text:
Roy Greenslade has become the Anthony Blunt of British journalism. His admission that he was a secret supporter of the IRA while working as a senior editor on a succession of newspapers, including The Sunday Times, was shocking (News Review, last week).

He retains his belief that attacks on innocent members of the public were justified despite what he calls a “painful moment” when the journalist Philip Geddes, 24, was blown apart by an IRA bomb outside Harrods in 1983. I used to sit on the next desk to Philip at the Daily Express. For us, it was beyond “painful”. It was devastating.

Sponsored

Rarely have two journalists been so mismatched. One young, talented, honest; the other a man who lived a lie —
summary:
Roy Greenslade has become the Anthony Blunt of British journalism.
His admission that he was a secret supporter of the IRA while working as a senior editor on a succession of newspapers, including The Sunday Times, was shocking (News Review, last week).
I used to sit on the next desk to Philip at the Daily Express.
For us, it was beyond “painful”.

title: The online harms bill misses the point
text:
The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted our almost complete reliance on the Internet, whether keeping business wheels turning, educating our children or contacting friends and family.

But the darker side of this digital dependency has been an exponential increase in illegal and legal online harms — from child abuse material to anti-vax disinformation and hate speech.

Sponsored

Before the pandemic, the UK launched an online harms white paper in 2019 that raised hopes of a safer digital future. Almost two years on, the government’s much anticipated proposals have finally been published; heavy with soundbites but short on detail, they will disappoint many.

Though impossible to please everyone, the shock-and-awe penalties in the paper — including swingeing fines and last chance saloon threats to target senior management —

title: Wealthy landowner’s views on one-child policy ‘crazy’
text:
Paul Lister is best known for his purchase in 2003 of the Alladale estate in Sutherland

A Highland landowner who is the heir to the MFI furniture fortune has provoked outrage by advocating “one woman, one child” population controls.

Paul Lister, who inherited an estimated £50 million from his father’s business, is best known for his purchase in 2003 of the Alladale estate in Sutherland, where he hoped to reintroduce wolves.

Sponsored

In a letter to members of his European Nature Trust, he said that Covid-19 had brought human society to “a tipping point”. “The wave we have been riding has now crashed ashore, and each of us will be required to change habits and make new choices in all aspects of our lives. None of us are exempt, nor will we be unaffected by the consequences of inaction; the alternative

title: Moscow coronavirus death toll rises by 3,000 after revision
text:
A guard closes the Iberian Gate in Red Square. Moscow has lifted most of its coronavirus restrictions

Russia

Moscow’s health department said today that the city had 5,260 coronavirus deaths in May, a figure far higher than the official toll of 1,895 for last month.

Russia’s Covid-19 taskforce says there have been a total of 3,085 deaths in Moscow since the start of the pandemic. It was unclear when or if the official figures would be updated.

Sponsored

The total number of fatalities in Moscow for May was 15,713, or 61 per cent higher than the number of deaths for the month over the past decade, health officials said. The number of deaths was even higher than in 2010, when Moscow was engulfed in a toxic smog.

The Moscow health department said that a review of its methods for calculating Covid-19 fatalities had

title: Gay Saudi woman says marriage vote and Leo Varadkar drew her to Ireland
text:
Alamri Amjaad says she is terrified of having to return to her home country

A gay Saudi Arabian woman claimed asylum in Ireland because of the marriage equality referendum and the fact that Leo Varadkar was taoiseach.

Alamri Amjaad, 22, arrived via Turkey in late February. She has applied for asylum because she claims that her life is at risk in her country due to her sexuality.

Sponsored

Speaking to The Times through an interpreter, she said she wanted to come to Ireland because the situation for women in Saudi Arabia was “very bad”. She added: “Simply, I am gay and I left Islam, I don’t believe in it anymore. It is against my rights as a gay person and a human.”

title: Spare us the mess of a grand Covid inquiry
text:
In the lexicon of political cliché there are some phrases so irritating, so alien to everyday parlance that it is a wonder those in Westminster continue to wheel them out. “Let me be frank” (prior to fudge), “Let me be clear” (prior to obfuscation), “Hard-working families” (translation: those people who drive white vans and eat budget sausage rolls). The worst offender has to be “lessons will be learnt”, its ghastly glibness indicating that instead of reflecting or apologising, the speaker intends to kick the can well beyond the horizon. Now, we are told, “lessons will be learnt” from the pandemic, with an independent inquiry at some point down the line.

title: Brenda Power: Nuns simply do as society asks, so now they take the blame for mother and baby homes
text:
In my convent primary school, there was an elderly, retired sister who would occasionally fill in for our usual kindly nun. That was never a good day. She was hard-faced and cross — in my memory she looks a bit like Samuel Beckett in a wimple — and as she took her seat after morning prayers, she’d place a gnarled knuckle of a furze branch, about a foot long, prominently on her desk. And she would use this, instead of the ruler our usual teacher favoured, to slap us for talking or for not knowing an answer; as little girls aged 8-12, those were the very worst of our transgressions.

The stick, which I often got to see up close, intrigued me. I imagined her
summary:

That was never a good day.

I imagined her

title: Scottish Opera’s Hansel and Gretel opera film
text:
Those of us disappointed by the lack of even medium-scale opera work by our big subsidised national companies during lockdown can take comfort from Scottish Opera’s second opera film of the season, Humperdinck’s Hansel and Gretel. A semi-staging of Mozart’s Così fan tutte in the autumn can still be watched on the company’s website.

The new film is directed by Daisy Evans, a rising figure in the world of operatic accessibility, with Kitty Whately and Rhian Lois as the titular children, nemesis of Nadine Benjamin’s Mother and Witch. Like the Così, the production was filmed in the company’s home, Glasgow’s Theatre Royal.

Sponsored

Humperdinck’s masterpiece is often regarded as an ideal children’s opera, perfect Christmas entertainment as a sung counterpart to Tchaikovsky’s ballet The

title: Two brothers charged over ‘honour killing’ of sister
text:
Two brothers have been charged with the murder of their 16-year old sister in a rare example of a so-called honour killing in Indonesia.

Rosmini binti Darwis was beaten and hacked to death with a machete after reportedly confessing to an affair with a distant male relative on the island of Sulawesi. Her brothers, Rahman, 30, and Surianto, 20, have been charged with her murder.

Sponsored

“The suspects said they were outraged when their sister admitted she had sex with a man who is their distant relative,” the local police chief, Wawan Sumantri, said. “This is a case of honour killing.”

Ms Rosmini died last month in the Bantaeng region of South Sulawesi. She had been in poor health, having suffered from nausea and dizziness, and
summary:
Two brothers have been charged with the murder of their 16-year old sister in a rare example of a so-called honour killing in Indonesia.
Rosmini binti Darwis was beaten and hacked to death with a machete after reportedly confessing to an affair with a distant male relative on the island of Sulawesi.

title: Cleared of rape: man who was unaware he had sex while asleep
text:
A man has been acquitted of rape after a jury accepted his claim that he was unaware sex was taking place because he was asleep.

Darrell Swanson, 39, told jurors that he suffered from a rare psychological condition called sexsomnia which meant that he was having intercourse during the night without knowing it. Mr Swanson, from Dunfermline, Fife, had denied three historical rapes, two of a woman now aged 36 and one involving her younger sister, now 30.

text:
The governor of a Russian region has been arrested on murder charges that critics say could be revenge for his landslide election victory over a rival from President Putin’s ruling party.

Sergei Furgal, 50, was shown being pulled from his vehicle by masked investigators wearing camouflage in footage broadcast by state media. He has not commented on allegations that he ordered the killings of businessmen in 2004-05.

title: You think British men are bad — try Aussies
text:
While young women in Britain have been mounting protests against misogyny and sexual assault, thousands of Australian women have joined rallies demanding a more robust response to harassment and assault — especially in parliament. I’m not surprised.

As an Aussie, I totally understand the reason for Antipodean female outrage. The catalogue of sexist behaviour is piling up, particularly in politics. Last month Brittany Higgins, a former ministerial press officer, claimed that she had been raped by a colleague in the office of the woman who is now Australia’s defence minister. Separately, a senior cabinet minister, the attorney-general Christian Porter, 50, has taken mental health leave after being accused of raping a teenager more than 30 years ago. title: Make throttling a crime to ensure tough sentences, say abuse groups
text:
Dame Vera Baird said: “The law as it stands is not fit for purpose”

The victims’ commissioner has lent her weight to a campaign to introduce a specific offence of throttling, survivors of which are seven times more likely to become the victim of a domestic abuse killing.

Women’s groups want the introduction of a crime of non-fatal strangulation so that domestic abusers face more punitive sentences.

title: Hawa Abdi obituary
text:
On New Year’s Day 1993, President George HW Bush travelled to the outskirts of Mogadishu, the Somali capital, where he was taken on a tour of Hawa Abdi Hope Village. His guide was “Mama Hawa” herself, a doctor who had turned her family’s farm and the surrounding land into a haven for those fleeing famine, civil war and poverty.

What had begun ten years earlier as a one-room clinic to help women in childbirth had grown into a 400-bed facility with a hospital, school and camp for displaced people; the compound was a makeshift city, one that for a time was home to 90,000 Somalis living in huts made from sticks and plastic sheets. Under Mama Hawa they received medical care, food and education. She
summary:
On New Year’s Day 1993, President George HW Bush travelled to the outskirts of Mogadishu, the Somali capital, where he was taken on a tour of Hawa Abdi Hope Village.
His guide was “Mama Hawa” herself, a doctor who had turned her family’s farm and the surrounding land into a haven for those fleeing famine, civil war and poverty.
What had begun ten years earlier as a one-room clinic to help women in childbirth had grown into a 400-bed facility with a hospital, school and camp for displaced people; the compound was a makeshift city, one that for a time was home to 90,000 Somalis living in huts made from sticks and plastic sheets.
Under Mama Hawa they received medical care, food and education.

title: Church knew of sex‑sadist priest Joseph Quigley years before police
text:
The report from late 2008, provided to officials at the Catholic Church, was damning. A priest had shown personality traits and behaviour consistent with sexual “sadism” and “voyeurism”, it concluded.

In the weeks before the findings, a man had approached the Archdiocese of Birmingham to speak out about Father Joseph Quigley. He wanted to make the church aware of his relationship with Quigley when he was aged 16 or 17, in the early 1990s. Over several years, the then sixth-former was told to “strip” during meetings and encouraged to perform sex acts in front of the priest.

title: Rape normal at private school, says dossier of 170 testimonies
text:
Highgate School in north London asked a victim of sexual assault to sign a non-disclosure agreement, according to one student

One of the country’s leading private schools has been accused of upholding a “rape culture” after governors were sent a dossier containing 170 testimonies of sexual abuse and harassment.

Former pupils at Highgate School, whose alumni include Sir John Betjeman and Michael Mansfield QC, alleged that pastoral staff repeatedly failed to act on accusations and one pupil attempted suicide after being raped by a fellow classmate.

Sponsored

The school, which charges fees of £21,600 a year, asked a victim of sexual assault to sign a non-disclosure agreement, according to one pupil, and was allegedly told by a staff member to consider “how legal ramifications for his actions might hurt his feelings”.

A pupil said she had been raped by one boy, sexually assaulted by two more
summary:

title: Here’s a blockbuster idea: a lie‑filled show about a TV boss’s family. I bet the Queen would watch
text:
I am three-quarters of the way through the latest series of The Crown, which is being shown on Netflix, and so far I’ve seen the funeral of Lord Mountbatten, overlaid with the soundtrack from an IRA statement on British oppression in Ireland. I’ve watched Princess Diana vomiting noisily and often. And I’ve heard Michael Fagan, the man who broke into Buckingham Palace, explaining to the Queen how so many lives were being ruined by Mrs Thatcher’s policies.

Meanwhile, the Queen Mother has not yet uttered a single pleasant or kind word, Prince Andrew has told his mother about what his latest girlfriend did with an aeroplane joystick, Prince Charles has been perpetually wet and useless and Mrs Thatcher has explained she doesn’t like women,

title: Robert De Niro: from Mean Streets to bread ads
text:
The showpiece scene in the recently released and mostly excruciating Robert De Niro “comedy” The War with Grandpa arrives midway through. It’s late at night and De Niro, as ornery grandfather Ed, who is locked in an escalating prank battle with grandson Peter (Oakes Fegley), is sleeping soundly in a large double bed.

Suddenly, a strange sixth sense awakens Ed. He turns to the empty space next to him, nervously reaches out and roughly whips back the sheets. Wriggling on the mattress is a live and significantly sized gopher snake, placed there as an intimidating statement by the young and ruthless Peter.

OK, so it’s not quite a horse’s head, but we get it — it’s a Godfather reference. De Niro played young Vito Corleone

text:
A prison officer has been jailed for almost two years after she invented rape claims against a taxi driver.

Victoria Hoynes, 27, from Durham, falsely said that she had been raped in the front seat of a taxi on the way home from a night out after it pulled up in front of a hospital. This led to two men being questioned by police and damage to their livelihoods, a court was told.

title: Domestic abuse victims need help now more than ever
text:
Being an outreach support worker for Women’s Aid during the lockdown has been a strange experience. No more face-to-face visits in women’s homes or the community and with new referrals, I have to imagine what the person on the other end of the phone might look like. I worried that home working would be difficult, that I would struggle to fill my time and questioned how effective I could be.

The reality has been very different. Women face the unenviable challenges of staying safe while locked down with an abuser all day every day, escaping if they can for an hour’s exercise or shopping and finding ways to protect their children and themselves.

text:
Samantha Crompvoets said being outside the military got her access to stories of alleged atrocities

She works in an airy office of women across a lake from Canberra’s commanding towers that house the overwhelmingly male military headquarters.

Dr Samantha Crompvoets, a military sociologist and founder of a small consultancy of female professionals in the Australian capital, infiltrated and won the trust of the toughest men soldiers. It would lead to the uncovering of an alleged war crimes scandal that for years eluded generals and others in command.

text:

A former senior figure at Celtic FC’s feeder team played a key role in ensuring that Tommy Burns was appointed manager of the Parkhead side, further undermining claims that the two clubs were separate entities.

title: Times letters: Vaccine refuseniks and the steps to freedom
text:
Sir, Clare Foges is right (“Vaccine certificates are vital step to freedom”, Comment, Mar 1). I do not wish to sit beside anyone in a concert hall, restaurant or cinema who has not been vaccinated. These people have the choice to refuse the vaccine and put themselves at greater risk, but surely the rest of the population who accept the vaccine, and want to keep themselves safe, should not have their health put at greater risk by having to be in close proximity with these foolish people. I had my first jab on Feb 1 and will have my second on April 12: I am grateful for it and for all those who have made it possible.

Roderick Boggs

Belfast

Sir, Clare Foges has produced

title: Alex Massie: Specialist rape courts have right to a fair trial in Scotland
text:
Imagine you are summoned for jury duty. Being a civic-minded soul, you recognise the importance of the task allotted you. It is a weighty responsibility, but one you embrace. You arrive at the High Court on the required date, filled with curiosity and, perhaps, a little nervousness, too. What kind of case might you get? Something interesting, you hope, but also one that will not require you to attend court for weeks on end. You are ready, however, and you know you will discharge your duties honestly and without prejudice. You are a fair-minded soul, after all. Everyone says so.

You are certainly the kind of person who will not bring their own views or prejudices with them to court. No, of course not. Just
summary:
Being a civic-minded soul, you recognise the importance of the task allotted you.
It is a weighty responsibility, but one you embrace.
You arrive at the High Court on the required date, filled with curiosity and, perhaps, a little nervousness, too.
Something interesting, you hope, but also one that will not require you to attend court for weeks on end.
You are certainly the kind of person who will not bring their own views or prejudices with them to court.

title: Child sex criminals escape prosecution
text:
Modern slavery laws were only used for underage offences 30 times in a year

Child sexual exploitation prosecutions have almost halved in three years and police action against offenders is “disappointingly low”, a charity has said.

The Children’s Society has disclosed that modern slavery laws — designed to target those, such as county lines drugs traffickers, who criminally exploit children — were only used for underage offences 30 times in a year, despite fears of rising abuse.

Sponsored

The charity warned that the scale of exploitation, whether sexual or criminal, remained “stubbornly high” while the number of perpetrators being charged and prosecuted for exploitation of children was “disappointingly low”. It called for a new law to help capture more offenders.

title: China is guilty of genocide against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang, says US report
text:
Canada, Britain and the EU joined the US last week in imposing new sanctions on four Chinese officials involved in the Xinjiang abuses

China is committing genocide and crimes against humanity against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang, the US State Department declared in its annual human rights report to Congress, raising the stakes in the superpowers’ fraught relationship.

Anthony Blinken, the secretary of state, verbally endorsed his predecessor, Mike Pompeo’s judgment that China was guilty of genocide during his confirmation hearing but the report is the first time the charge has been formally laid before Congress.

Sponsored

The State Department is required to submit the report annually to Congress for the government to take countries’ human rights into consideration when formulating trade and foreign policy.

The 2019 report under the Trump administration accused the Chinese government of a campaign of mass detention of Uighurs and other Muslim minorities in camps
summary:
Canada, Britain and the EU joined the US last week in imposing new sanctions on four Chinese officials involved in the Xinjiang abusesChina is committing genocide and crimes against humanity against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang, the US State Department declared in its annual human rights report to Congress, raising the stakes in the superpowers’ fraught relationship.
Anthony Blinken, the secretary of state, verbally endorsed his predecessor, Mike Pompeo’s judgment that China was guilty of genocide during his confirmation hearing but the report is the first time the charge has been formally laid before Congress.

title: Stop Bloody Bossing Me About by Quentin Letts review — waging war on the finger-waggers
text:
People walking past my house and hearing loud rhythmic grunts coming through the window know what I’m doing — voicing loud assent to every sentence written by Quentin Letts, who rants very eloquently about Greta Thunberg (“moody little madam”), the National Trust (stately homes turned into “kiddies’ play areas”), schools that ban pop guns (because they “symbolise aggression”) and the “bossocracy” who have put a stop to drinking straws, dirty weekends in Barcelona and fox hunting (“an act of political spite against Barbour-wearers”), to name only a few targets.

The forebears of our contemporary scene, as Letts sees it, would be Oliver Cromwell, who stamped out revelry, Mary Whitehouse, who didn’t like swearing, and Barbara Woodhouse, who house-trained spaniels. Everywhere pusillanimity and finger-wagging reigns.

Sponsored

Nurseries
summary:
People walking past my house and hearing loud rhythmic grunts coming through the window know what I’m doing — voicing loud assent to every sentence written by Quentin Letts, who rants very eloquently about Greta Thunberg (“moody little madam”), the National Trust (stately homes turned into “kiddies’ play areas”), schools that ban pop guns (because they “symbolise aggression”) and the “bossocracy” who have put a stop to drinking straws, dirty weekends in Barcelona and fox hunting (“an act of political spite against Barbour-wearers”), to name only a few targets.

A lawyer who represented victims of Harvey Weinstein has been hired to investigate whether top modelling agencies may have facilitated alleged sexual abuse and trafficking.

title: Sentence ‘too lenient’ for teenager who slashed woman’s throat on date
text:
The offender lured his victim to an isolated area in Dún Laoghaire where he tried to kill her

The Court of Appeal has found that the 11-year sentence for a teenager who attempted to murder a woman he met on a dating app was too lenient.

The court said that the element of planning and premeditation meant that “even as attempted murders go” the offence had to be seen as being at the high end of the spectrum.

The Director of Public Prosecutions had appealed, arguing that a review of the sentence imposed on the teenage boy after a five-year period was too early.

The now 17-year-old, who cannot be named because he is a minor, has been in custody since December 2017, when he lured Stephanie Ng to an isolated area at Sea Front, Queen’s Road, Dún Laoghaire.
