title: Twitter bans Trump permanently for glorifying violence
text:
Mr Trump has used Twitter to announce policy, sack colleagues and stoke domestic tensions

President Trump has been banned permanently from Twitter, severing forever his favourite way of communicating with his supporters.

The social network explained a move it had resisted for years by saying that Mr Trump’s recent tweets, in which he called his supporters “great American patriots” and declared he would not attend Joe Biden’s inauguration, posed a “risk of further incitement of violence”.

Sponsored

The account, which was followed by 89 million people, was at once a source of immense rallying power and a display window for Mr Trump’s most grievous excesses.

His unprecedented rise from television stardom to the Oval Office was propelled in no small part by his instinctive grasp of what conservative grassroots craved from the then-nascent platform.

Mr Trump had been suspended on

title: Rape charge for high society internet tycoon Lawrence Jones
text:
A British tech tycoon who counts the rich and famous as friends has been charged with rape and sexual assault.

Lawrence Jones, 52, who is said to be worth £700 million, founded the internet hosting service UK Fast and was its chief executive until he stepped down in 2019 after allegations by female colleagues made during an investigation by the Financial Times.

Sponsored

They had included inappropriate physical contact, verbal abuse and bullying, which he denied at the time. The company, based in Manchester, had been ranked as one of the top ten places to work in Britain.

Greater Manchester police said yesterday that Mr Jones, who lives in Hale Barns, a village near Altrincham, had been charged with one rape and four sexual assaults.
summary:
A British tech tycoon who counts the rich and famous as friends has been charged with rape and sexual assault.
Lawrence Jones, 52, who is said to be worth £700 million, founded the internet hosting service UK Fast and was its chief executive until he stepped down in 2019 after allegations by female colleagues made during an investigation by the Financial Times.
SponsoredThey had included inappropriate physical contact, verbal abuse and bullying, which he denied at the time.
The company, based in Manchester, had been ranked as one of the top ten places to work in Britain.
Greater Manchester police said yesterday that Mr Jones, who lives in Hale Barns, a village near Altrincham, had been charged with one rape and four sexual assaults.

title: Sex-crime victims can choose gender of interviewer
text:
Dame Vera Baird QC said: “Under the victims’ code, everyone has a right to support following a crime”

Victims of rape and sexual violence will be able to choose the gender of the police officer interviewing them under plans to bolster the rights of victims.

It is among 12 rights being introduced as part of a “victims’ code”, which comes into force today and will set out the minimum level of service victims can expect from criminal justice agencies such as the police and courts.

Sponsored

Victims of serious crimes will be offered the option of receiving automatic alerts when their perpetrator is released from jail. They will also be offered support to challenge Parole Board decisions to release criminals.

Victims of foreign criminals will get the right to know when they are deported under the new code, which ministers say is a stepping

Food distribution and Packaging

€341m (£300m) ▲€43m

One of Northern Ireland’s biggest businesses, W&R Barnett has worldwide interests including molasses, animal feed, grain, oils, commodity trading, laboratory testing, storage and packing. It is chaired by Barnett, 76, the fourth generation to run the family conglomerate, founded in Belfast in 1896 as a grain merchant.

The man accused of murdering Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe “wore the shooting like a badge of honour” when he moved to America and believed he was “beyond the long arm of the law”, a court was told.

Lorcan Staines SC, for the prosecution, in his closing speech told the court that Aaron Brady was a “skilled and practised liar” who told a “litany of lies” to gardaí and to the jury.

title: Young lives have shrunk to the size of a screen
text:
Two weeks into home-schooling my teenage daughter, we have fallen back into a routine first established last spring. Every day begins with me shouting at her to get out of bed and turn on her laptop for school work. Every day ends with me shouting at her to put her phone down. In between, she spends at least 16 hours hooked up to the internet and staring into a device.

Once we worried about what children got up to online. Anxious parents shared tips for limiting screen time. Articles were written about the damage too much exposure to blue light could inflict upon children’s eyes. There was concern that the growth of online gaming was making youngsters more sedentary. Most of all, we worried about
summary:
Two weeks into home-schooling my teenage daughter, we have fallen back into a routine first established last spring.
Every day begins with me shouting at her to get out of bed and turn on her laptop for school work.
Every day ends with me shouting at her to put her phone down.
In between, she spends at least 16 hours hooked up to the internet and staring into a device.
Articles were written about the damage too much exposure to blue light could inflict upon children’s eyes.

title: Star female gamer, 19, ‘murdered by rival’
text:
Ingrid Oliveira Bueno da Silva, 19, is thought to have gone to the home of Guilherme Alves Costa, right, to play in a competition

A talented Brazilian female player in the male-dominated world of professional video gaming has been murdered by a fellow competitor.

The body of Ingrid Oliveira Bueno da Silva, 19, was found at the São Paulo home of Guilherme Alves Costa, 18. The two had played for rival teams in the game Call of Duty: Mobile. She is understood to have gone to Alves Costa’s house on Monday expecting to take part in a joint competition after making contact online last month.

title: China condemned by Mike Pompeo after report of mass sterilisation of Uighurs
text:
China has been accused of displaying an “utter disregard for the sanctity of life” after a German researcher claimed Beijing had used mass sterilisation and forced abortions to suppress birth rates in its restive Uighur minority by as much as 80 per cent.

The report, based on leaked Chinese communist party (CCP) documents, suggested that up to 34 per cent of married Uighur women of reproductive age had been targeted with a campaign of sterilisation surgery and contraceptive implants.

Sponsored

The authorities in the province of Xinjian aimed to sterilise at least 80 per cent of women who were capable of having children in four southern districts, according to Adrian Zenz, senior fellow in China studies at the Victims of Communism foundation in Washington.

text:
Facebook has admitted that changes to end-to-end encryption on its messaging services will make it easier for paedophiles to share images of child sexual exploitation.

Last year Mark Zuckerberg promised to introduce the technology on Facebook Messenger to protect users’ privacy. At present the company can monitor conversations between users.

title: Abuse puts girls off a career in politics, says Oxford High head teacher
text:
Girls are being put off careers in politics by the abuse of well-known women, the new head of a school says.

Pupils at Oxford High, whose alumnae include Dame Cressida Dick, the Metropolitan Police commissioner, and Dame Margaret Hodge, a former Labour minister, hosted an online conference for female politicians yesterday.

Sponsored

Marina Gardiner Legge, who took over as head teacher in September, said: “There are currently 650 MPs in the House of Commons, of which just over a third are women, the highest number ever, but this still isn’t good enough. title: Libby Squire murder: butcher with history of sex crimes found guilty
text:
Libby Squire was attacked by Pawel Relowicz in Hull in February 2019

A married butcher who used his family car to stalk the streets for young women after dark has been convicted of raping and murdering a student on a night out.

Pawel Relowicz, 26, left his wife and two young sons sleeping at home and scoured Hull until he saw Libby Squire, 21, vulnerable and alone after a night drinking with friends in February 2019.

title: Face to face with the cycle of abuse: one foster carer’s chance encounter
text:
Whenever I hear the term “toxic masculinity”, I think of a little boy called Charlie, a frequent visitor to our house when I was a young teenager. Charlie was the son of Jill, a neighbour my mother had befriended who was a victim of domestic abuse. It wasn’t unusual for Jill to seek sanctuary with our family after closing time, her pale face creased with pain as she ushered her bleary-eyed son into our house.

I’ll never forget the evening I responded to a frantic knocking at the door and found her in a pitiful state, a distraught Charlie clasped to her hip. Heavily pregnant, she had managed to rescue the child from the crossfire of a particularly vicious attack and had escaped before her
summary:

title: Met police officer accused of rape by two colleagues was not suspended
text:
Both women were awarded substantial sums last year after the compensation authority concluded that police evidence indicated that they had suffered serious sexual and physical abuse

A serving officer with the Metropolitan Police accused of rape by two female colleagues has continued working since the allegations surfaced four years ago.

The officer, who has not been charged, was restricted in his interactions with the public but the force has not prevented him from working with female colleagues.

Sponsored

The two co-workers accused him of sexual and physical abuse but the case was not taken up by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), according to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism.

However, the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA), which compensates the victims of violent crimes, awarded both women substantial sums last year after concluding that police evidence indicated that each had been the victim of serious sexual and physical abuse.

The government-run CICA assesses cases
summary:

text:

She lived like this, she said, because she was so scared of Peter Nygard, the Canadian fashion mogul, who she claims trafficked her from Canada to the Bahamas and raped her when she was in her twenties.

title: Woman who staged murder victim’s suicide sent back to prison
text:
The Central Criminal Court was told that Janice Brady was suspected of repeated shoplifting and had moved without telling her probation officer

A woman serving a suspended sentence for staging a murder victim’s suicide has been sent back to jail having been charged with more than 30 new offences.

Janice Brady, 30, moved into a B&B in Dublin without informing her probation officer in March and was warned that she would be sent back to jail if she did not keep in contact with the probation service. A warrant was issued for her arrest this month when she broke the terms of her probation again and the Central Criminal Court was told that she had been charged with 32 more offences, mostly shoplifting in Dublin.

title: Jewish women need more protection from racist abuse
text:
Today is International Women’s Day. Choose to Challenge is the theme and it has resonated strongly with me. Like those of us who come from immigrant backgrounds with strong women at the forefront, the matriarchs in my family chose to challenge the prejudices they faced as working class, immigrant, Jewish women long before they realised their equal future in the world, or indeed feminism became a movement.

I have discovered that Jewish women have long held a special place in the heart of Jew haters and misogynists. In recent years I chose to challenge. Sticking my head above the social media parapets to speak out, I have experienced this very specific type of targeted hate I would imagine my great grannie Annie faced when arriving
summary:
Today is International Women’s Day.
Choose to Challenge is the theme and it has resonated strongly with me.
Like those of us who come from immigrant backgrounds with strong women at the forefront, the matriarchs in my family chose to challenge the prejudices they faced as working class, immigrant, Jewish women long before they realised their equal future in the world, or indeed feminism became a movement.
I have discovered that Jewish women have long held a special place in the heart of Jew haters and misogynists.

title: “I risked our lives to flee”: escaping domestic violence in lockdown
text:
It’s close to midday and a young mother is freewheeling a bicycle down a slope on the communal lawn of a women’s refuge with a carefree expression on her face. Nearby her three-year-old stands barefoot in the warm June sunshine, looking somewhat bemused at his mum’s new-found playfulness. He begs for a ride and a smile spreads across his face.

For years Gemma, 23, and her son were subjected to horrific abuse and control at the hands of her husband. Only now can she savour the simple pleasure of playing with her child without fear. They are among a small number of women and children who have found sanctuary at this refuge for victims of domestic abuse in the north of England. Nestled on a
summary:
It’s close to midday and a young mother is freewheeling a bicycle down a slope on the communal lawn of a women’s refuge with a carefree expression on her face.
Nearby her three-year-old stands barefoot in the warm June sunshine, looking somewhat bemused at his mum’s new-found playfulness.
For years Gemma, 23, and her son were subjected to horrific abuse and control at the hands of her husband.
Only now can she savour the simple pleasure of playing with her child without fear.
They are among a small number of women and children who have found sanctuary at this refuge for victims of domestic abuse in the north of England.

title: What the critics are watching and listening to, from Promising Young Woman to Iggy Pop
text:
Promising Young Woman

This is a film, in no uncertain terms, about misogyny. It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned. But it’s also a movie that crackles and fizzes with style and wit and blackly humorous subtext. It’s written and directed by Emerald Fennell, aka Camilla Parker Bowles in The Crown, making her feature debut with a gobsmacking display of authorial nous. Fennell fills each scene with characters and situations that seem dramatically real, then symbolic, then real again. Carey Mulligan is perfectly cast as Cassandra, a brittle coffee shop barista dealing with the death of her best friend, the victim of a university rape and subsequent downward spiral. But Cassandra is also an avenger and a symbolic

Sponsored

It’s the story of a rape, and a suicide, and a life upturned.

Fennell fills each scene with characters and situations that seem dramatically real, then symbolic, then real again.

title: Reclaim data as well as the streets to make women safe
text:
Just days on from the Metropolitan Police confirming the appalling murder of Sarah Everard the government has already been able to announce changes in an attempt to help women feel safer. Doubling the money given to the Safer Streets Fund for more CCTV cameras and better street lighting is a tangible and swift response. Government were able to act quickly because problems with personal safety are already understood. So why do women in the UK feel unsafe now more than ever?

Women’s experience of personal safety is dramatically different to mens. And the data government collects on women’s experience of personal safety is poor. The most common form of violence women experience is sexual harassment; this isn’t the experience of men; and it isn’t measured
summary:
Just days on from the Metropolitan Police confirming the appalling murder of Sarah Everard the government has already been able to announce changes in an attempt to help women feel safer.
Government were able to act quickly because problems with personal safety are already understood.
Women’s experience of personal safety is dramatically different to mens.
And the data government collects on women’s experience of personal safety is poor.
The most common form of violence women experience is sexual harassment; this isn’t the experience of men; and it isn’t measured

title: Roman Frackiewicz: Woman found dead at home had 14 fractured ribs, murder trial told
text:
Jadwiga Szczygielska’s injuries were in keeping with blunt force blows, the High Court in Edinburgh was told

An elderly woman alleged to have been murdered by a lodger in her home had sustained extensive chest injuries, a court has been told.

Jadwiga Szczygielska, 77, sustained 14 fractured ribs and a broken breastbone as well as collapsed lungs and a rupture to the heart.

Sponsored

Ian Wilkinson, a consultant forensic pathologist who carried out a post-mortem examination, told the High Court in Edinburgh that a traffic collision would be one situation where he would expect to see such injuries.

The court was told that they could be in keeping with blunt force blows to the chest or the application of sustained blunt force pressure.

Roman Frackiewicz denies murdering Ms Szczygielska at the flat where they lived in Seafield, Edinburgh, on April 17 last year.
summary:
Jadwiga Szczygielska’s injuries were in keeping with blunt force blows, the High Court in Edinburgh was toldAn elderly woman alleged to have been murdered by a lodger in her home had sustained extensive chest injuries, a court has been told.

title: Andra Day on playing Billie Holiday: I drank, I smoked, I lost three stone
text:
She takes the stage with stately poise — jaw set, killer frock, a gardenia in her hair. Under a single spotlight she sings Strange Fruit, the chilling portrait of a lynching that became one of the first protest songs and made its singer a target for the American government. You won’t see many better performances than Andra Day’s in The United States vs Billie Holiday. Her portrayal of Holiday in the film captures the woman’s full complexity; by turns imperious and vulnerable, glamorous and wretched, warm and cold. Day has been nominated for two Golden Globes for best actress in a drama and best original song for the Strange Fruit-inspired Tigress and Tweed. Few would be surprised if the Oscars followed

title: I was raped by my close friend, says Poldark star Ciara Charteris
text:
Ciara Charteris said she shut her eyes and “passed out in terrified defeat”

Ciara Charteris, one of the stars of Poldark, has revealed that she was raped by a close friend five years ago.

The 25-year-old actress said she had plucked up the courage to report the incident to police only last year, after a “best friend” broke their pact to cut the alleged attacker out of their lives.

Sponsored

Charteris, who played Emma Tregirls in the BBC drama, said that the betrayal “broke” her and led her finally to speak up.

The man alleged to have raped her was a “slightly older” friend, whom she had known since she was 16.

“Although I have struggled to say the word ‘rape’ out loud for a long time, I knew that’s what had happened.

title: Dame Floella: I told Queen about torment of racism
text:
When seated next to the Queen at lunch, many would be lost for words. Not Floella Benjamin.

The former Play School presenter, now a Liberal Democrat peer, had lunch with the monarch when she visited Exeter University, where Baroness Benjamin was chancellor in 2012. They sat together and chatted about food, children, the House of Lords — and racism.

Sponsored

Benjamin, 71, says on today’s Desert Island Discs on BBC Radio 4: “I told her my story. And I said, ‘Ma’am when I was a little girl in Trinidad I used to sing God Save the Queen but how badly I was treated when I came to England. And now here we are sitting together having lunch. Who would have thought?’ We really, really hit it

title: British girl stuck in Syrian camp was trafficked at 12 then raped
text:
Syria’s Roj camp, pictured, and Al Hol camp are thought to house nine British men, 16 women and 34 children

A British girl who was trafficked to Syria at the age of 12 and then raped and impregnated by an Islamic State fighter is among 50 women and children stranded in refugee camps.

A report from the campaign group Reprieve reveals that two thirds of British women detained in northeast Syria were coerced and trafficked to the region before being sexually exploited.

Sponsored

The group says that many were under 18 when they travelled to Isis territory and have suffered years of exploitation, including forced marriage, rape and domestic servitude.

Some have since had their own children, who are denied basics such as education and consular assistance. Reprieve argues that the government is “systematically failing trafficking victims” by not bringing them home.

text:
Mislaid on Banbury Road in Oxford some time in 1934: a small swastika brooch belonging to Miss Barbara Pym, a gift from her Nazi boyfriend. It may still be lying there.

title: More claims of sex abuse on university campuses
text:
Two more Scottish universities are investigating claims of sexual abuse on campus after students posted accounts of rape and harassment online.

Details of ten incidents have been written on a “Stirling Survivors” forum on Instagram, while students at Aberdeen University have also shared allegations of sexual misconduct.

Sponsored

It comes after St Andrews students used an Instagram page to detail 50 first-hand allegations of rape, sexual assault and harassment this month.

On the Stirling University forum, one student claims to have been raped and assaulted by a male student they met at a nightclub after refusing three times to have sex with him. The incident was reported to the police but “because it was an issue of consent, no charges were pressed,” the student said.

title: Melanie Bramwell-Popham: I made a promise to Alix’s daughters that I would keep their dad here for as long as possible
text:
Popham, who won 33 caps for Wales, had dementia diagnosed last year in a devastating blow for his young family

Melanie Bramwell-Popham wept on Monday as she read Val Vickerman discuss the death of her son.

Dan Vickerman, who won 63 caps for Australia, took his own life nearly four years ago, at the age of 37. His mother is convinced he died from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), the degenerative disease found in people with a history of repetitive brain trauma.

Sponsored

“I do believe that if CTE had been spoken about he may have been able to cope with what was happening in his life,” she told The Times.

Bramwell-Popham wept because she agreed. She wept because she recognised so acutely the symptoms Val Vickerman had described. She wept because she knew the same fate could so easily have befallen her husband.

Alix

title: Tory MP accused of rape stays away from parliament
text:
The MP has voluntarily agreed not to return to parliament when the summer recess ends on September 1

A former Conservative minister arrested on suspicion of rape has agreed not to return to Westminster next month after his bail was extended to November.

The MP has voluntarily agreed not to return to parliament when the summer recess ends on September 1. Opposition MPs had called for him to be suspended but the Conservatives are resisting calls to remove the whip.

Sponsored

A spokesman for the whips’ office said: “These are serious allegations and it is right that they are investigated fully. A decision on the whip will be reviewed once the police investigation has been concluded.”

The MP was taken into custody in east London on August 1 and then released pending investigations.

title: Times letters: Sir Ian Botham and cronyism in the Lords
text:
Sir, I am stumped to understand the logic behind Sir Ian Botham’s forthcoming appointment to the House of Lords (“Botham given peerage as reward for Brexit loyalty”, July 18). The award of a peerage should not be a “thank you” to chums, as it carries with it significant governmental responsibility, and should be reserved for those who have clearly demonstrated the wisdom, statesmanship and experience for such high office.

Ironically, at the same time that we see populism and cronyism dominating the recent honours lists, many who have faithfully served their country are being denied appropriate recognition. The present chief of the air staff, Air Chief Marshal Mike Wigston, who has been in post for a year, has yet to receive a knighthood;
summary:
Sir, I am stumped to understand the logic behind Sir Ian Botham’s forthcoming appointment to the House of Lords (“Botham given peerage as reward for Brexit loyalty”, July 18).
The award of a peerage should not be a “thank you” to chums, as it carries with it significant governmental responsibility, and should be reserved for those who have clearly demonstrated the wisdom, statesmanship and experience for such high office.

title: On record: pop, rock and jazz — October 25
text:
ALBUM OF THE WEEK

BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN

Letter to You

Columbia

All successful songwriters end up competing with their younger selves. Bruce Springsteen, reunited on record with the E Street Band for the first time since 2014, gives a sly nod to this truth by including freshly minted recordings of three songs from the early 1970s (one of them being the notorious and semi-mythical If I Was the Priest). Their inclusion is apt, for Letter to You is a headily nostalgic affair; sonically, it takes you back to the glory days of Born to Run, Darkness on the Edge of Town and The River. There is something profoundly moving about the sound of Bittan, Tallent, Weinberg et al leaning right into the music;

Sponsored

text:
A review of historical records at Merchiston Castle School found it had failed to protect some children from abuse in the past

The head of a boys-only independent boarding school has told an inquiry that concerns of a “predatory culture” are an issue for all schools.

Jonathan Anderson, headmaster at Merchiston Castle School in Edinburgh, said it was “not fair” to single out boys-only schools over the issue.

Sponsored

Giving evidence at the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry, Anderson said his school had done a “harrowing” review of files and accepted there may have been abuse between 1930, when the school moved to Colinton, and 2014.

Andrew Brown QC, counsel to the inquiry, questioned him on recent media reports that boys’ schools can produce a “predatory culture”.

title: Demonising boys won’t change toxic culture
text:
Three weeks ago, my teenage daughter mentioned that her Instagram feed was suddenly full of testimonies from girls talking about appalling sexual abuse they had suffered at school and university. “Read them and weep,” she said, “it’s even worse than I thought.” I was horrified. One of my teenage sons had also seen postings on Everyone’s Invited. “It’s barbaric,” he said.

I eventually tracked down the website’s founder, Soma Sara, who lives with her grandmother in Paris; the 22-year-old was polite, charming and quietly spoken but determined. She’d been trying for nine months to get people to listen to her and her friends’ stories of rape culture. It was only when she started to mention schools by name that Everyone’s Invited went viral on

title: Line of Duty viewers crack link to murder of Maltese journalist Caruana Galizia
text:
Daphne Caruana Galizia, with her son Matthew, was the inspiration for the fictional journalist Gail Vella, right

Viewers attempting to unravel the knotty plot of Line of Duty may be intrigued to learn that the murder victim at its centre is based on a real person.

Jed Mercurio, the writer of all six series of the BBC police drama, has been scrolling through Twitter to congratulate fans who have spotted the resemblance between the fictional journalist Gail Vella and Daphne Caruana Galizia.

title: Michel Fourniret: Ogre of Ardennes admits murder of a 12th woman
text:
Michel Fourniret, centre, in 2006. He is serving a life sentence without parole for the murders of seven women and girls

France’s most notorious living serial killer has admitted killing a 29-year-old woman in 1993, bringing to 12 the murders he is known to have committed.

Michel Fourniret, 78, known as the Ogre of the Ardennes, acknowledged that he was responsible for the death of Lydie Logé, who vanished from Saint-Christophe-le-Jajolet in Normandy.

Sponsored

Fourniret has been serving a life sentence without parole since 2008 for the murders of seven women and girls in France and Belgium. Police confronted him with DNA from a mattress in his van that matched that of Logé’s mother.

A Conservative MP who was accused of rape, sexual assault and coercive control is free to return to parliament after police confirmed they had dropped their investigation into him.

text:
Mr Justice Paul McDermott at the central criminal court in Dublin said the man sought out children for his own gratification

A child rapist who used his membership of a voluntary paramedic organisation to target two boys who he then drugged and sexually assaulted has been jailed for nine and a half years.

The 29-year-old Co Kildare man used an oxygen mask to force one 15-year-old victim to inhale a pain relief drug before sexually assaulting him. In a second attack the accused raped the unconscious child while another man recorded it on his mobile phone.

Sponsored

The man, who cannot be named to protect the identity of the victims, pleaded guilty at the central criminal court in Dublin to oral rape of one boy at a place in Co Laois on May 7, 2018. He also admitted meeting the child for the purpose of sexual exploitation
summary:

title: Row grows over failure to suspend Tory MP accused of rape
text:
The former minister was questioned at an east London police station after allegations made by a former parliamentary aide

The Conservative Party is under mounting pressure to suspend a senior MP who has been arrested on suspicion of raping a former parliamentary aide, after the alleged victim said she was devastated that the action had not been taken.

Some Tory MPs have privately expressed dismay at the decision made by Mark Spencer, the chief whip, not to take action against the MP until the police investigation has concluded.

Sponsored

One former Conservative minister said their colleague should “of course” be suspended from the whip pending the outcome of the police investigation. “Whether an MP has the whip or not is totally irrelevant during recess,” they said. “That, and consistency, are both arguments for suspension.”

A female Conservative MP said she was “shocked” by the allegations
summary:

title: ‘It’s not going to help Hearts in the long term if I fall out with people’
text:
When Dundee turn up at Tynecastle for the opening game in the Championship their directors will get a friendly welcome in the Hearts boardroom. No, really. They won’t need to worry about vinegar in the tea or salt in the coffee. “Absolutely,” says Andrew McKinlay, Hearts’ new chief executive, laughing at the very notion. “I’m sure we will be as hospitable as we would be to any directors. I think we’re just all looking forward to getting the football started. It’s interesting that Dundee are first.”

title: David Quinn: Down’s syndrome abortion equates to eugenics
text:
The long-running British soap opera Emmerdale has landed itself in hot water because a forthcoming episode features a couple deciding to abort a child diagnosed with Down’s syndrome. This has outraged families who have children with this condition, and for good reason.

As Wendy O’Carroll, the founder of UK support charity Ups and Downs, said in an open letter to Emmerdale: “Your proposed story will further serve to encourage and confirm the opinion that ending the life of a baby just because it has Down’s syndrome is perfectly acceptable and understandable because maybe it would be better if fewer people ‘like them’ were in the world.”

title: Boris Johnson and Joe Biden can be a powerful force against sexual violence in conflict
text:
Following Joe Biden’s victory in the US election last week, the UK has seen a flurry of comment on what it all means for the prime minister, Brexit, and the future of the relationship between Britain and America.

As the UK government looks for ways to work with the Biden administration over the next four years, its best bet is to drill down into the detail and work out a few key areas where UK and US values are aligned — and, crucially, to develop specific proposals for what steps the two countries can actually take together. Close and regular co-operation, often on fairly technical, nuts and bolts issues, is the bedrock of the “special relationship”.

Sponsored

But it is specific action which will give meaning
summary:

title: Modelling agent Jean-Luc Brunel linked with Jeffrey Epstein arrested on rape charges
text:
Jean-Luc Brunel, who disappeared from public view after the death of Jeffrey Epstein, is accused of rape, sexual assault on minors, and human trafficking

A powerful French modelling agent accused of rape and of procuring hundreds of women and girls for Jeffrey Epstein was arrested in Paris yesterday.

Jean-Luc Brunel was detained on suspicion of rape, sexual assault on minors, human trafficking and involvement in a criminal conspiracy, the Paris prosecution office said in a statement. He was arrested at Charles-de-Gaulle airport while preparing to take a flight to Dakar in Senegal, according to a police source.

Sponsored

Along with Ghislaine Maxwell, the British socialite in prison in New York awaiting trial, Mr Brunel is alleged to have had a pivotal role in the Epstein scandal, supplying the US financier with the women and girls who became his victims. Epstein hanged himself in a cell in New York in 2019
summary:

Jean-Luc Brunel was detained on suspicion of rape, sexual assault on minors, human trafficking and involvement in a criminal conspiracy, the Paris prosecution office said in a statement.

title: I won’t be decolonising, I’ve no shame about empire
text:
Rather suddenly, something people call “colonialism” has become the root of all evil. Monuments, statues, the National Trust, stately homes, Cambridge colleges, the school curriculum, even the BBC, are suddenly diagnosed as suffering from this distressing condition. If the gents at Derby station isn’t as clean as one might like, colonialism is probably to blame. We are instructed to decolonise as a matter of urgency.

Well, this child of empire has no intention of decolonising and nor will I betray my forebears or the ideals of my youth. I am proud of empire. I recognise that for Britain its time has passed; that its motives were mixed; that its attitudes are now outdated; that colonialism did terrible as well as many good things, and there
summary:
Rather suddenly, something people call “colonialism” has become the root of all evil.
Monuments, statues, the National Trust, stately homes, Cambridge colleges, the school curriculum, even the BBC, are suddenly diagnosed as suffering from this distressing condition.
If the gents at Derby station isn’t as clean as one might like, colonialism is probably to blame.
Well, this child of empire has no intention of decolonising and nor will I betray my forebears or the ideals of my youth.
I am proud of empire.

title: Gun crimes and violence soar as gangs settle scores after lockdown
text:
Police forces had tried to take advantage of lockdown to arrest known gang members

Violence on the streets has surged to levels not seen since before Covid-19 alongside sharp rises in gun crime as gangs settle scores and enforce debts.

Firearms were discharged in London at nearly twice the rate last month as the same period last year and Scotland Yard recorded its third highest month for violent crimes in a decade.

Sponsored

Gangs recovering lost profits and a lack of enforcement as they laid low in the lockdown have blighted other towns and cities too, Matt Perfect, head of the National Crime Agency’s firearms response, told The Times.

The Met said that last month there were 24 “lethal-barrelled” discharges compared to 40 last month.

“It’s not unique to London,” Mr Perfect said, adding that Manchester and the

title: Can your relationship survive the second wave?
text:
In normal years the divorce calendar has two spikes on it; one after the summer holidays, followed by a much larger one post-Christmas.

You can almost look at divorce like a virus, and this year it is spreading atypically, at present rising rampant across the western world in a bumpy upward curve. The first wave started to climb shortly after the peak of coronavirus, with a brief abatement during the lightening of the skies, load and rules during the summer. Now cases are building at unusually high rates again. Are you becoming hyper-aware of someone else’s toenails, whether attached to their host or not? Has your relationship got enough immunity to survive the winter Covid-strain?

Sponsored

Or, as Eric Spiegelman, a podcast executive, wrote on social
summary:
In normal years the divorce calendar has two spikes on it; one after the summer holidays, followed by a much larger one post-Christmas.
You can almost look at divorce like a virus, and this year it is spreading atypically, at present rising rampant across the western world in a bumpy upward curve.
The first wave started to climb shortly after the peak of coronavirus, with a brief abatement during the lightening of the skies, load and rules during the summer.
Are you becoming hyper-aware of someone else’s toenails, whether attached to their host or not?
Has your relationship got enough immunity to survive the winter Covid-strain?

title: Policewoman’s baby taken into care after NHS error
text:
The couple, whose identities are hidden in this illustration, endured ‘a nightmare’

A police detective and her husband were arrested and had their children taken into foster care after a hospital wrongly diagnosed fractures in their baby.

The ordeal began last October after their eight-month-old rolled off a double bed in their home near Wrexham, north Wales, and broke his leg.

Sponsored

His mother, 32, had left him for a few seconds as she grabbed a nappy liner. She heard a thud, followed by a cry of pain. Her first reaction was to take her son to hospital. It triggered a series of events that she still relives in flashbacks.

text:

I give you, as a for-instance, Jimmy Savile, who couldn’t have provided a bigger clue as to his true nature short of getting “paedo” tattooed on his forehead. Scott Rudin, the film and theatre producer revealed as a shocking bully, offered no such evidence. Could be he was lovably benign. Could be he was the unpleasant person he in fact turns out to be.

title: Accused of Murdering Our Son: The Steven Clark Story review — no one has a clue in this fascinating mystery
text:
Accused of Murdering Our Son: The Steven Clark Story

ITV

★★★☆☆



This Is My House

BBC1

★★☆☆☆

The disappearance of Steven Clark is a proper, tragic, old-fashioned mystery and one which I felt at the end of Accused of Murdering Our Son: The Steven Clark Story might never be solved. In 1992 a 23-year-old man walked into a seaside public toilet while his mother visited the ladies and was never seen again. Apart from a couple of alleged sightings in the days afterwards, it is as though he has vanished off the face of the Earth. It’s the sort of thing Netflix might make a moody true-crime documentary about if the leads weren’t so scant and it was Salt Lake City not Saltburn-by-the-Sea in North

title: Exiled Bolivian former president Evo Morales accused of rape
text:
Evo Morales is accused of having a sexual relationship with a minor

The ousted Bolivian president Evo Morales has been accused of statutory rape and human trafficking by the country’s justice ministry.

Guido Melgar, the deputy justice minister, told a press conference in La Paz yesterday that his department had filed a criminal complaint against Mr Morales, 60, over his alleged sexual relationship with a minor.

Sponsored

Details surrounding the alleged relationship emerged this month. Photographs have been published in Bolivian newspapers showing Mr Morales with a young woman, who has been identified only by the initials NM.

title: China Room by Sunjeev Sahota review — this novel deserves to win prizes
text:
We expect certain things from a multigenerational family saga set in India. Colour, food, demotic speech, a little bit of magic. We expect a fat book with a pretty, bright jacket thanks to those heady days when Arundhati Roy, Vikram Seth et al led western readers safely through a post-colonial literary landscape. In fact, it was Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children that compelled Sunjeev Sahota to become a writer; it was the first novel he read, when he was 18.

Sahota is now one of Britain’s most fêted young novelists. His second novel, The Year of the Runaways, was shortlisted for the Booker prize in 2015 and he was one of the “40 under 40” chosen by the Royal Society of Literature to bring their

title: Ghislaine Maxwell: My accuser has her eye on Epstein payout
text:
Ghislaine Maxwell has launched a “vicious” attack on one of her key accusers, claiming she fabricated allegations about Maxwell’s involvement in child sex abuse because of a “desire for cash”.

Lawyers for the British socialite have sought to cast doubt on the credibility of Annie Farmer after it emerged she could receive “millions of dollars” from a compensation fund for victims of Jeffrey Epstein, the American paedophile financier and former boyfriend of Maxwell.

Sponsored

Farmer, who claims she was abused by the couple when she was 16, is one of three women preparing to testify against Maxwell this summer in her criminal trial on charges of child sex trafficking and perjury. Maxwell denies all the charges. She faces up to 35 years in jail if convicted.

Sky Atlantic

★★★★☆

I was loving the dour intensity of Mare of Easttown until three minutes before the end when, oh, here we go again (spoilers ahead), back on crime drama’s very favourite carousel — a beautiful, naked, murdered young woman. title: Justine McCarthy: Séamus Woulfe has revealed why we should wig out
text:
Séamus Woulfe would have been best advised to heed the proverb that discretion is the better part of valour. Had he gone quietly along to meet former chief justice Susan Denham for her non-statutory review of his attendance at the Oireachtas Golf Society dinner in Clifden and accepted a formulaic chiding, the whole sorry saga would be over by now, at least for him and his bewigged colleagues, if not for an appalled public poleaxed by a pandemic. Instead, he armed himself with a top-notch senior counsel and a scattergun of recriminations, thus prolonging his purgatory and, worse, demonstrating to his lofty Supreme Court fellow judges why he simply is not their sort.

Across the frozen vista of last week’s suspended process to deal with

title: Robert Webb: ‘The doctors literally switched me off. A lung and heart machine was breathing for me’
text:
Robert Webb does laps of Queen’s Park three times a week, running the perimeter outside, not inside any more, because he can’t stand the other “arsehole” runners, “who think because they go faster, they have right of way”. And he can’t stand the dog-walkers – “I hate dog-walkers” – or, in fact, people in general; especially the ungrateful bastards who didn’t notice him skidding about in the mud trying to give them space, which is what forced him onto the pavement. As he jogs, in an old pair of gas-blue trainers, tracksuit bottoms (shorts if the temperature is in double digits, “never” leggings), he mutters a little mantra in time with his footfall and breathing: “You’re a c***. You’re a c***. You’re a c***.” Occasionally

title: The King’s School calls in police after pupils share rape jokes online
text:
The King’s School in Grantham has contacted police after the comments by pupils in a live Instagram broadcast

A grammar school that boasts Sir Isaac Newton among its former pupils has contacted police after students took part in an Instagram chat where pupils swapped jokes about rape.

The King’s School in Grantham, Lincolnshire, confirmed that some of its pupils were involved in a live Instagram broadcast last Monday.

Sponsored

Simon Pickett, the school’s head teacher, said it would be taking “appropriate action” and had contacted police after complaints over the broadcast.

Sreenshots of the comments on the chat included one that said: “I’d take rape as a compliment” and another that read: “What do 9 out of 10 people enjoy? Gang rape.” Others described women as “objects”, while another said that women should “wake up and realise your [sic] never going to have equality”.
summary:
The King’s School in Grantham has contacted police after the comments by pupils in a live Instagram broadcastA grammar school that boasts Sir Isaac Newton among its former pupils has contacted police after students took part in an Instagram chat where pupils swapped jokes about rape.
The King’s School in Grantham, Lincolnshire, confirmed that some of its pupils were involved in a live Instagram broadcast last Monday.

Gang rape.” Others described women as “objects”, while another said that women should “wake up and realise your [sic] never going to have equality”.

title: Muslims accept France’s secular values
text:
The “charter of republican values” is central to President Macron’s campaign against terrorism

French Muslim leaders have approved a charter rejecting radicalism and accepting equality between the sexes in a success for President Macron’s plan to promote an “enlightened Islam”.

The rejection of fundamentalist doctrines and acceptance of secular values is contained in a text drafted over the past six weeks by the French Council of Muslim Worship (CFCM), which represents the faith in relations with the state.

Sponsored

The “charter of republican values” is central to Mr Macron’s campaign against a culture of what he describes as separatism and foreign interference hostile to French society. A new system to license imams will require all preachers to sign the charter.

summary:

The rejection of fundamentalist doctrines and acceptance of secular values is contained in a text drafted over the past six weeks by the French Council of Muslim Worship (CFCM), which represents the faith in relations with the state.

title: ‘Inaccuracies’ in mother and baby homes report
text:
A Protestant woman who gave evidence to the Mother and Baby Homes Commission has said the record of her testimony in the final report is inaccurate and depicts her as a Catholic.

“a social worker” drove her there. In fact, the clergyman was a Church of Ireland canon and the social worker was with Pact, previously known as the Protestant Adoption Society.

title: Child abuse inquiry ‘scared of racist tag’
text:
Sarah Champion says victims were let down

The national inquiry into child abuse refused to investigate Britain’s most notorious sex-grooming scandals and barred key witnesses from giving evidence, it has been revealed.

Victims and experts blamed the decision not to examine mass offending in Rotherham and Rochdale on a “cowardly” reluctance to look at a pattern of group crimes in which men of Pakistani heritage have been over-represented.

title: George Floyd’s family lawyer Ben Crump on America’s year of soul-searching
text:
When Ben Crump describes himself as “black America’s attorney-general”, he really means it. In one blockbuster case after another the Florida lawyer has become the face of the African-American struggle against police brutality and extrajudicial killings. In 2020, a year unlike any other, that role put him at the very centre of American life.

When the 29-year-old Jacob Blake was shot seven times in the back during a police encounter in Kenosha, Wisconsin, Crump took to the airwaves on his behalf. When Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, was shot dead by police raiding her Kentucky apartment in March, Crump represented her family. Responding to a gunshot fired by her boyfriend, the officers shot Taylor six times while entering her home as part of a

title: Warwick University student raped on campus condemns ‘toxic culture’
text:
A student at Warwick University said that the institution had a culture of not taking women’s claims seriously

A student at Warwick University who has said that she was raped on campus has accused the vice-chancellor of presiding over a “toxic” culture.

Jane — not her real name — said that she had been attacked by one of her flatmates in March while living in halls of residence. She has reported the incident to the police and the university.

title: Abuse inquiry: Welfare fears about postwar child migration
text:
UK local authorities were reluctant to take part in child migration to Australia after the Second World War because of concerns over welfare, an inquiry has been told.

Mark Davies, of the UK government’s Department of Health and Social Care, told the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry he had found evidence that councils were hesitant to send children in their care and had raised concerns over the level of welfare they were receiving.

Sponsored

Mr Davies told Colin MacAulay, QC, senior counsel to the inquiry: “It is quite clear that many of the authorities did not send children to Australia after the Second World War. It looks very likely that the majority were of the opinion migration was not suitable for children.”

The inquiry was told that

title: Dublin Rape Crisis Centre warning after drop in sex assault crimes
text:
Noeline Blackwell, of the Dublin Rape Crisis Centre, said the figures were not consistent with the number of offences “actually happening”

There has been a drop in the number of reported sexual offences for the first time in almost six years, according to new crime statistics.

The Dublin Rape Crisis Centre cast doubt over the figures, saying that sexual offences are often under-reported.

Sponsored

There were 3,114 sexual offences reported in the 12 months to March this year, 149 fewer than the same period last year. This is a decrease of 4.6 per cent and is the first year-on-year decrease since the third quarter of 2014 when 1,849 incidents were reported.

The figures, from the Central Statistics Office (CSO), also show that the number of reported sexual offences reached a record high of 3,307 last year.

title: Hundreds of Rohingya land after ‘six months at sea’
text:
Hundreds of stateless Rohingya Muslims who have landed in Indonesia, mostly women and children fleeing persecution in their native Burma, say they have spent six months at sea.

According to the authorities in the Indonesian province of Aceh, almost 300 of the refugees, the biggest group to land in the country since 2015, came ashore early yesterday morning at Ujung Blang beach near the city of Lhokseumawe.

Sponsored

The group had been at sea for six months, said Chris Lewa of the Arakan Project, a human rights organisation that monitors the movement of Rohingya refugees. According to reports from Aceh, it consisted of 181 women, 102 men and 14 children.

title: We must restore public trust in justice
text:
The rigorous inspection and analysis of our criminal justice system is crucial to enhancing the quality of justice and restoring public confidence.

As attorney-general, I oversee two key partners of the criminal justice system in England and Wales — the Crown Prosecution Service and the Serious Fraud Office — which are responsible for securing justice for hundreds of thousands of victims annually.

Sponsored

The government is unwavering in its commitment to supporting victims, securing justice and protecting our communities — especially from serious and violent crimes, such as rape and serious sexual offences, child abuse and domestic abuse.

title: Victim of Children of God cult member tells of years of abuse as child
text:
Derek Lincoln, 74, has been jailed for more than 11 years

A woman who was sexually assaulted as a child living in a religious commune in Scotland has spoken of her ordeal after her abuser was sent to prison for his crimes.

Hope Bastine, 41, was born into the Children of God (CoG) cult and endured years of sexual abuse at the hands of Derek Lincoln, a “missionary” member of the group.

Sponsored

On Friday, Lincoln, also known as John Green, was sentenced to 11 years and six months in prison for the rape and sexual assaults of two young girls. Lincoln abused the girls at addresses in Ayrshire, Renfrewshire and Lanarkshire from the ages of 9 and 11. The offences took place between 1989 and 1996.

Bastine was born in 1979 and during the 1980s lived

title: Lord Janner: Family of former Labour MP accused of trying to stop public inquiry into child abuse claims
text:
Daniel Janner, QC, Lord Janner’s son, “vilified and insulted the inquiry, day after day”, it was claimed

The family of a former Labour MP and peer was accused yesterday of using “friends in high places” to try to stop a public inquiry into child abuse allegations against him.

The children of the late Lord Janner of Braunstone were accused of insulting his alleged victims and vilifying the efforts of the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA) to examine the claims.

Sponsored

Lord Janner died aged 87 from Alzheimer’s disease in December 2015, while awaiting a “trial of the facts” on 22 sexual offence charges.

The allegations on the indictment came from nine men, most of whom were former residents of Leicestershire children’s homes who claimed they were sexually assaulted when Lord Janner was a Labour MP in Leicester between 1970-97.

IICSA’s investigation
summary:

title: Nicola Sturgeon isn’t the feminist she’d have us all believe
text:
After Nicola Sturgeon released an “unscripted” Twitter video addressing the issue of young people leaving the SNP over failure to support the trans community, the first minister said she would re-evaluate gender recognition reform and that an independent Scotland would be an equal one for all. But can we take her seriously?

Her commitment to what she called woke issues are often celebrated but be careful. On the surface her reforms seem sparkling with promise but underneath sits murky water. I support LGBTQ+ reform but if the slow change in women’s representation under the SNP is anything to go by, change isn’t coming.

title: Facebook privacy plans ‘will make it honeypot for child sex offenders’
text:
Installing end-to-end encryption on Facebook Messenger and Instagram could create a “superplatform” for paedophiles, according to one expert

Facebook has been warned that its privacy plans will make it a “honeypot” for child sexual offenders after figures revealed that its encrypted WhatsApp service yielded only 26 abuse tip-offs to law enforcement in a year.

Rob Jones, director of threat leadership at the National Crime Agency (NCA), said that “the lights would go out” and offenders would go undetected if Facebook followed through with its plans to install end-to-end encryption on the social media site.

Sponsored

Using the technology on Facebook Messenger and Instagram could create a “superplatform” for paedophiles, as its WhatsApp messaging service already has privacy controls to block detection of child abuse and retrieval of evidence.

text:
No seamy reimaginings of Hercule Poirot, no brand-new retro ghost stories with Mark Gatiss, no Charles Dickens extravaganza: there were, for obvious reasons, noticeable absences in this year’s Christmas TV schedules. There was, however, no need to be brave, knuckle down and make the best of Mrs Brown’s Boys just yet. (Not that anyone’s missed their chance now it’s slated to appear every December 25 until 2026. Imagine a pink cardigan smothering a human face for ever.)

text:

Turkish-backed militias fighting the Assad regime in Syria are committing war crimes against Kurdish civilians, including rape and torture, the UN has said.

title: Govan GPs found model to handle tough cases but rollout failed
text:
When John Montgomery, a GP, met Nicola Sturgeon, he says she backed the new approach he and colleagues were taking.

The team at Govan Health Centre were doing just what the first minister envisaged: working with other health and social care staff to look after vulnerable patients in a bid to reduce the pressure on emergency healthcare.

Sponsored

Yet when the three-year pilot, funded by the Scottish government, ended in 2018, the doctors could not get the funding and staff needed to continue. The new approach has stalled, and patient requests for appointments are soaring. “It was a great shame,” Montgomery said.

title: Natasha Golding: Woman ‘raped on island’ must pay thousands to attend trial
text:
Natasha Golding has been told she will not be giving evidence at the Cape Verde hearing

A British woman who claims she was raped on a Cape Verde island more than two years ago will not be called as a witness at the trial of her alleged attacker.

Natasha Golding, 44, from Leeds, has fought to make sure that her alleged attacker faces justice. She is concerned about the outcome in a country that she claims has never prosecuted a rape.

Sponsored

Ms Golding was told last month that under Cape Verde’s criminal justice system it was not necessary for the alleged victim to play a role in any trial. The court would rely instead on her statements.

She was also told that she would have to pay her own way to any trial and that she would have to hire translators.
summary:
Natasha Golding has been told she will not be giving evidence at the Cape Verde hearingA British woman who claims she was raped on a Cape Verde island more than two years ago will not be called as a witness at the trial of her alleged attacker.

She is concerned about the outcome in a country that she claims has never prosecuted a rape.
SponsoredMs Golding was told last month that under Cape Verde’s criminal justice system it was not necessary for the alleged victim to play a role in any trial.
She was also told that she would have to pay her own way to any trial and that she would have to hire translators.

title: Independent watchdog to police abusive priests
text:
Measures set out by the Church were described as a “root and branch” overhaul

The Church of England has acknowledged that bishops cannot be trusted to investigate their own priests and will bring back “defrocking” to kick out paedophiles, in an overhaul of how sexual abuse cases are handled.

Bishops will be stripped of their powers to investigate and punish abuse cases after a critical report last autumn found that the church had harboured hundreds of paedophiles over almost 70 years and that allegations against priests had routinely been ignored, minimised or dismissed by church leaders.

Sponsored

The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse (IICSA) found that in many cases, abusive priests or bishops were allowed to continue their ministry for decades before finally facing justice, leaving their victims with no support or recognition.

title: Mugabe’s violent youth militia could be ready to march again
text:
A national youth service programme that spawned a violent militia that carried out some of the worst excesses of Robert Mugabe’s rule in Zimbabwe is to be revived.

Kirsty Coventry, 37, the minister of youth and the only white person in the government, proposed its resurrection to instil patriotism and loyalty among people aged 18 to 35, according to a cabinet briefing note. It has provoked fears that the unit is being readied before a bloody general election in 2023 and has led to fresh criticism of Coventry, a retired Olympic swimmer. Last year she was criticised for taking a lease on a prized farm that was seized during Mugabe’s catastrophic land grab.

title: State of Happiness review — oil rigs and fish: it’s Mad Men, Norwegian-style
text:
State of Happiness

BBC Four

★★★★☆

Van der Valk

ITV

★★★☆☆

Sponsored

My list for a good time emphatically would not contain any of the following: oil rigs, fish factories, no pubs and a Norwegian winter. State of Happiness majored heavily in all of these, and sometimes it was all quite, well, heavy. However, it is also set in 1969, which meant that we got the antidote of Mad Men-type fashion, period hairstyles, lovely old cars and drinking in work meetings (those were the days) as we prepare to see Stavanger amid the oil boom of the 1970s.

The producers have apparently denied that this is “Norway’s Mad Men”. Fine, but I was sure I could detect shades of depressed, neurotic, super-smoker Betty Draper

title: Irish charity uncovers child sexual abuse in 32 countries
text:
The Irish charity Hotline there needed to be cross-border co-operation in the fight against online child sexual abuse

An Irish charity uncovered child sexual abuse material from 32 countries including Ireland last year.

Hotline.ie is the Irish national centre of expertise for combating illegal content online, providing a web-reporting service on which members of the public can securely report child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and activities.

Sponsored

Hotline.ie revealed its findings in response to a consultation by the European Commission. The commission is exploring whether to establish a European centre to prevent and counter child sexual abuse.

In July 2020, the commission published a strategy for a “more effective fight against child sexual abuse”. It includes eight initiatives for the 2020-2025 period including to put in place a strong legal framework, strengthen the law enforcement response and facilitate a co-ordinated approach across the many
summary:

Hotline.ie is the Irish national centre of expertise for combating illegal content online, providing a web-reporting service on which members of the public can securely report child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and activities.
SponsoredHotline.ie revealed its findings in response to a consultation by the European Commission.
The commission is exploring whether to establish a European centre to prevent and counter child sexual abuse.

title: Seven sex attacks in women’s jails by transgender convicts
text:
Trans men and women committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded in prisons between 2010 and 2018

Transgender prisoners are five times more likely to carry out sex attacks on inmates at women’s jails than other prisoners are, official figures show.

Male prisoners who were transferred to women’s jails during gender reassignment and women inmates who are transitioning committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded between 2010 and 2018. They occurred at HMP Low Newton in Co Durham, Foston Hall in Derbyshire, Peterborough, Bronzefield in Middlesex and New Hall, West Yorkshire.

Sponsored

Karen White, a child abuser who dressed as a woman but was still legally a man, was jailed for life in 2018 for sexually assaulting two prisoners at HMP New Hall and the rape of a woman while he was outside jail.

Lord Keen of Elie, the Ministry of Justice
summary:
Trans men and women committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded in prisons between 2010 and 2018Transgender prisoners are five times more likely to carry out sex attacks on inmates at women’s jails than other prisoners are, official figures show.
Male prisoners who were transferred to women’s jails during gender reassignment and women inmates who are transitioning committed seven of the 124 sex attacks recorded between 2010 and 2018.
They occurred at HMP Low Newton in Co Durham, Foston Hall in Derbyshire, Peterborough, Bronzefield in Middlesex and New Hall, West Yorkshire.
SponsoredKaren White, a child abuser who dressed as a woman but was still legally a man, was jailed for life in 2018 for sexually assaulting two prisoners at HMP New Hall and the rape of a woman while he was outside jail.
Lord Keen of Elie, the Ministry of Justice

title: Scottish child abuse inquiry has cost £40m despite six-month pause
text:
Lady Smith said that her findings about the Christian Brothers case study were being prepared for publication

The cost of the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry has now exceeded £40 million, according to the latest figures.

Data show that over 92 days the inquiry, led by Lady Smith, received £27,505.53 per day.

Sponsored

The inquiry was paused for six months from March but has since resumed, and the Child Migrations case study concluded on October 21, after hearing evidence in person or via a video link.

In her most recent newsletter, Lady Smith said that her findings about the Christian Brothers case study were being prepared for publication.

“Work in relation to my case study findings in relation to the Benedictines and Marists is also underway and they will be published as soon as possible,” she said. Public funding of £40,946,729 has supported the

title: Ross Thomson takes legal action against rival MP over unfounded sexual misconduct claims
text:
The former Conservative MP Ross Thomson, who was cleared of sexual misconduct against a Labour politician in a Westminster bar, is launching legal action against his accuser.

Thomson, who was Boris Johnson’s Scottish campaign manager during the Tory leadership contest, has also called for Paul Sweeney to be suspended by Scottish Labour and for the party to hold an investigation into his conduct.

Sponsored

Any suspension would almost certainly curtail Sweeney’s chances of becoming an MSP at May’s Holyrood election. He is third on the Glasgow regional list at present, so would be likely to be returned, but could lose his place amid potential disciplinary procedures.

A letter from Thomson’s solicitors, Ledingham Chalmers, to Anas Sarwar, leader of Scottish Labour, and to its UK and

title: EU is becoming policeman of the internet
text:
The Americans innovate and the Europeans regulate. That was a simple way of explaining the interaction between government and the technology business. It is still broadly true. The European Union is not quite an innovation desert but nothing rivals Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook or Microsoft. The US has flubbed questions such as internet privacy, whereas the EU is a rule-making superpower. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) of 2018 has become, in effect, a global standard.

Now the EU is flexing its muscles again, issuing proposed regulations on the hottest topic in digital governance: artificial intelligence, or AI. That is well overdue. Computer decision-making can determine whether you get a job, a loan, a home or a date, as well as what news or ads
summary:
That was a simple way of explaining the interaction between government and the technology business.
The European Union is not quite an innovation desert but nothing rivals Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook or Microsoft.
The US has flubbed questions such as internet privacy, whereas the EU is a rule-making superpower.
Now the EU is flexing its muscles again, issuing proposed regulations on the hottest topic in digital governance: artificial intelligence, or AI.

title: Survivors of child abuse need support as well as justice
text:
By my late twenties I had worked all over the world, a dream of mine, before landing a regular presenter’s slot on Sky Sports. But my achievements in adulthood concealed a childhood racked with trauma.

When I spoke out about the sexual abuse I suffered as a child, I did so because I believe these conversations need to take place in the open. Stigma and isolation are an abuser’s best friend. The abuse I endured left me feeling lonely and ashamed, even though the shame was my abuser’s to bear.

Sponsored

The former home secretary Sajid Javid and I both feel that we can and must do more for survivors of child sexual abuse. That’s why we have joined forces with the Centre for Social Justice
summary:
By my late twenties I had worked all over the world, a dream of mine, before landing a regular presenter’s slot on Sky Sports.
When I spoke out about the sexual abuse I suffered as a child, I did so because I believe these conversations need to take place in the open.
The abuse I endured left me feeling lonely and ashamed, even though the shame was my abuser’s to bear.
SponsoredThe former home secretary Sajid Javid and I both feel that we can and must do more for survivors of child sexual abuse.
That’s why we have joined forces with the Centre for Social Justice

title: Cardinal George Pell knew about child abuse, inquiry finds
text:
Cardinal George Pell knew that children were being sexually abused by Catholic priests as early as the early 1970s but failed to take action, an Australian inquiry has found.

The cardinal, 78, once appointed the Vatican’s third in charge by Pope Francis, had been “conscious” of child sexual abuse when he was a young priest and failed to act on complaints about abusive priests, a royal commission said. Cardinal Pell has denied the commission’s findings.

Sponsored

Cardinal Pell was released from prison last month after his conviction for child sexual abuse in 2018 was quashed. He was acquitted after a successful appeal to the High Court and has always maintained his innocence.

The publication of the report today was delayed while the criminal case was concluded.
summary:
Cardinal George Pell knew that children were being sexually abused by Catholic priests as early as the early 1970s but failed to take action, an Australian inquiry has found.
The cardinal, 78, once appointed the Vatican’s third in charge by Pope Francis, had been “conscious” of child sexual abuse when he was a young priest and failed to act on complaints about abusive priests, a royal commission said.
Cardinal Pell has denied the commission’s findings.
SponsoredCardinal Pell was released from prison last month after his conviction for child sexual abuse in 2018 was quashed.
He was acquitted after a successful appeal to the High Court and has always maintained his innocence.

title: No action against Callum Hudson-Odoi over rape allegation
text:
Hudson-Odoi was arreste4d at his home in west London in the early hours of May 17

A police investigation into rape allegations made against England and Chelsea forward Callum Hudson-Odoi has been closed with no further action taken.

Hudson-Odoi, 19, was arrested at his home in west London in the early hours of May 17 after the Metropolitan Police received a report of an unwell woman. The woman was taken to hospital by ambulance and Hudson-Odoi was taken into police custody.

Sponsored

He was released on bail and officers opened an investigation, but Hudson-Odoi announced today that no action was being taken against him.

“At a time where there are bigger things happening in the world right now, you may also be aware of serious allegations that were made against me,” he said in a statement posted on Twitter.

title: The rise of Mohammed bin Salman, in 10 steps – from $50 million parties to the murder of Jamal Khashoggi
text:
Right: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 34, photographed by Luca Locatelli. Top left: with Jeff Bezos. Below left: at the G20 summit in Osaka, 2019

1 Throw a $50 million party for your friends

Mohammed bin Salman had hit Riyadh harder and faster than any prince in recent memory. He had taken charge of Saudi Arabia’s economy, been given carte blanche to spend its billions, made commander of the armed forces and launched a war in Yemen. By now, in 2015, the deputy crown prince was mentioned so frequently by the media he needed an abbreviation: MBS. It was time to celebrate.

One boatload after another of models – Brazilian, Russian – pulled up to the dock at Velaa Private Island in the Maldives. Once they had settled into their villas, the seaplanes carrying Mohammed bin Salman and his friends arrived.

Sponsored

The Maldives were the perfect choice: a stunning setting

Below left: at the G20 summit in Osaka, 20191 Throw a $50 million party for your friendsMohammed bin Salman had hit Riyadh harder and faster than any prince in recent memory.

title: How to stop the Covid crisis becoming a hunger crisis
text:
The IMF’s updated economic growth projection predicts a striking 4.9 per cent contraction for this year – a much steeper decline than anticipated in April. Little wonder their report is called “a crisis like no other”. Tragically it is not only the numbers that make this unprecedented. So is the feeble global political response.

The G20, created to fight the last crisis, has been modest in ambition and impact. While national economic policy has innovated, international policy, from debt relief to aid flows, has been inert. That makes this week’s G20 finance ministerial meeting a test of whether the international community, including the UK, has what it takes to minimise the damage coming our way.

Sponsored

The International Rescue Committee’s new analysis shows that economic shocks
summary:
The IMF’s updated economic growth projection predicts a striking 4.9 per cent contraction for this year – a much steeper decline than anticipated in April.
Little wonder their report is called “a crisis like no other”.
The G20, created to fight the last crisis, has been modest in ambition and impact.
While national economic policy has innovated, international policy, from debt relief to aid flows, has been inert.
That makes this week’s G20 finance ministerial meeting a test of whether the international community, including the UK, has what it takes to minimise the damage coming our way.

title: The best historical fiction for October 2020 — farewell Uhtred, son of Uhtred
text:
Simon & Schuster, 496pp; £16.99

In the closing days of the First World War a young veteran is found in the Galilee Chapel of Durham Cathedral. He has lost his memory and cannot even remember his name. Named Adam Galilee by a sympathetic policeman, he is moved to a crumbling psychiatric hospital in Cumbria. There he comes into the care of James, a doctor who also served in the trenches. He lives at the institution with his wife, whose twin brother was killed fighting alongside James on the Western Front. Their loving marriage is tested by James’s survivor guilt and his terrible night terrors. title: Woman tasered and arrested after two men die at house
text:
Police were called to a disturbance at the house at about 4.30am yesterday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of murder after two men died at a house in east London.

The 28-year-old suspect was tasered by the police who had been called to a disturbance at the semi-detached house in Ilford at 4.30am yesterday.

Sponsored

Inamul Hussain, 32, a neighbour, said he called the police after hearing a woman screaming at the house.

“I saw them taser her, she had blood on her. I heard police say, ‘Put the knife down,’” he said. “She was screaming something about her husband but it was quite broken, I think they’re Polish. Several men and several women live there, they are always partying and drinking.”

title: The boy who grew up in the shadow of Elvis
text:
When police in Calabasas, LA County received reports of shots fired at an apartment last Sunday morning, news wires didn’t immediately light up. Sure, the wealthy community is home to Justin Bieber and Khloé Kardashian. Yet reports said that a 27-year-old called Benjamin Keough had shot himself in the stomach, taking his own life. Wait, Benjamin who?

Benjamin Keough was Elvis Presley’s grandson, the second oldest child of Lisa Marie Presley, (he took the surname of his musician father Danny Keough to whom Lisa Marie was married for six years). Benjamin lived a mostly quiet life and avoided the public gaze, but his apparent suicide — joining the grim dead-at-27 roll-call that includes Amy Winehouse, Jim Morrison, Jimi Hendrix, Kurt Cobain and many others —
summary:
